revision.text:
{{pp-move-indef}} '''Jenkem''' is an [[inhalant]] and [[hallucinogen]] created from fermented [[human waste]].Fuller, Alexandra (2005). The effects can be super dramatic including [[seizures]], [[vomiting]], and [[hallucinations]] [http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/ngm/0509/feature6/text4.html We just want enough.] ''[[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]]'', Volume 208, Issues 1-3, p. 119 In the mid-1990s, it was reported to be a popular [[street drug]] among [[Zambia]]n street children. They would put the feces and urine in a jar and cover it with a balloon then let it ferment out in the sun, then afterwards they would inhale the fumes created.Donaldson, Aidan (2010). ''Encountering God in the Margins: Reflections of a Justice Volunteer.'' Veritas, {{ISBN|978-1-84730-220-5}}{{cite news |first=Ishbel |last=Matheson |title=Children high on sewage |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/406067.stm |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=July 30, 1999 |accessdate=2007-07-06 }}[http://www.aegis.com/news/ap/1999/ap990703.html "African Children Orphaned by AIDS"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070706080137/http://www.aegis.com/news/ap/1999/AP990703.html |date=2007-07-06 }} [[Associated Press]], 1999 In November 2007, there was a [[moral panic]] in the United States after widespread reports of jenkem becoming a popular recreational drug in middle and high schools, though the true extent of the practice has since been called into question.Collier County Sherriff's Office (September 26, 2007). [http://www.thesmokinggun.com/documents/crime/new-drug-alert Information Bulletin: New Drug - JENKEM.] via ''[[The Smoking Gun]]''{{cite web |url=http://www.salon.com/mwt/feature/2007/11/09/jenkem/?source=rss |title=Smoke this shit |accessdate=2007-11-09 |author=Pietras, Jamie |date=November 9, 2007 |publisher=[[Salon.com]]}} Several sources reported that the increase in American media coverage was based on a hoax and on faulty [[Internet research]].{{cite web |url=http://urbanlegends.about.com/library/bl_jenkem.htm |title=Jenkem — Drug Warning |accessdate=2007-11-07 |last=Emery |first=David |date=November 6, 2007 |work=urbanlegends.about.com |publisher=[[About.com]]}} ==Description== The name derives from [[Genkem]], a brand of glues which had "become the generic name for all the glues used by [[Inhalant abuse|glue-sniffing]] children" in South Africa, where the drug originated and is most popular on the African continent today.Cassere, Di (November 14, 2000). [http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/glue-loses-high-to-save-street-kid-addicts-1.53018 Glue loses high to save street-kid addicts.] ''[[Independent Online (South Africa)|The Independent]]'' In the book ''Children of AIDS: Africa's Orphan Crisis'' by Emma Guest, the making of jenkem is described: "fermented human sewage, scraped from pipes and stored in plastic bags for a week or so, until it gives off numbing, intoxicating fumes."{{cite book |last=Guest |first=Emma |title=Children of AIDS: Africa's Orphan Crisis |url= |accessdate= |edition=2nd|year=2003 |publisher=Pluto Press |location= |isbn=978-0-7453-2075-5 |oclc= |page=149 |chapter=Falling through the net. A street child's story, Zambia |chapterurl= |quote= }} The process is similarly described in a 1995 [[Inter Press Service|IPS]] report: "Human [[excreta]] is scooped up from the edges of the sewer ponds in old cans and containers which are covered with a [[polyethylene]] bag and left to stew or ferment for a week." A 1999 [[BBC]] article refers to "the dark brown sludge, gathering up fistfuls and stuffing it into small plastic bottles. They tap the bottles on the ground, taking care to leave enough room for [[methane]] to form at the top." The effects of jenkem inhalation last for around an hour and consist of auditory and visual [[hallucinations]] for some users. In 1995, one user told a reporter it is "more potent than [[cannabis]]."{{cite news |title=Zambia-Narcotics: 'Huffing and Puffing' to a new High |publisher=[[Inter Press Service]] |date=August 26, 1995}} (reprinted in a Snopes.com [http://www.snopes.com/crime/warnings/jenkem.asp article on jenkem], retrieved December 30, 2007.) A 1999 report interviewed a user, who said, "With glue, I just hear voices in my head. But with jenkem, I see visions. I see my mother who is dead and I forget about the problems in my life." Fumito Ichinose, an anesthesia specialist in Boston who conducted a study on the effects of [[hydrogen sulfide]] gas, or "sewer gas," on mice, informed [[Salon (website)|Salon.com]] that holding your breath, choking, or "the inhalation of gases like those produced from jenkem could result in [[hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]], a lack of oxygen flow to the body that could be alternately euphoric and physically dangerous." ==Media reports== ===1995–2006=== The second media description of jenkem came from an [[Inter Press Service]] wire report in 1995. According to a 1998 report in ''[[The New York Times]]'', Fountain of Hope, a [[non-profit organization]], said that jenkem was used by [[street children]] in [[Lusaka]], [[Zambia]] to obtain a "powerful high".{{cite news |first=Suzanne |last=Daley |title=In Zambia, the Abandoned Generation |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/18/world/in-zambia-the-abandoned-generation.html?pagewanted=2 |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=September 18, 1998 |accessdate=2015-03-11}} (Spelled ''Jekem'') In 2002, Project Concern International Zambia and Fountain of Hope released a report entitled "Rapid Assessment of Street Children In Lusaka", where jenkem is listed as the third most popular drug among Lusaka's street children, following [[Cannabis sativa|Dagga]] (Cannabis) and "glue and Dagga" but ahead of "Ballan" (uncured tobacco) and [[Gasoline|petrol]].{{Cite journal | last = Zambia | first = Project Concern International | author-link = | last2 = Lemba | first2 = Dr. Musonda | author2-link = | publication-date = | date = March 8, 2002 | year = | title = Rapid Assessment of Street Children In Lusaka | edition = | volume = | series = | publication-place = Lusaka, Zambia | place = | publisher = [[UNICEF]] | id = | isbn = | doi = | oclc = | url = http://www.unicef.org/evaldatabase/files/ZAM_01-009.pdf | accessdate = 2007-11-12 | postscript = }} John C. Zulu, director of the Ministry of Sport, Youth and Child Development in Zambia, said in November 2007 that jenkem usage is less common than [[glue-sniffing]] and, "Initially, they used to get it from the sewer, but they make it anywhere ... They say it keeps them warm and makes them fearless." In 1999, [[BBC News]] ran a story about jenkem. In 2004, South African weekly investigative newspaper ''[[Mail & Guardian]]'' mentioned jenkem abuse in a report on Zambia's street children.{{cite news |first=Zarina |last=Geloo |title=Bleak outlook for Zambia's street kids |url=http://mg.co.za/article/2004-12-29-bleak-outlook-for-zambias-street-kids |publisher=[[Mail & Guardian]] |date=December 24, 2004 |accessdate=2015-03-11 |quote=Marijuana was used most commonly, along with glue for sniffing, jenkem (fermented sewage), petrol and cocaine. Street children also smoke, and drink alcohol.}} ===2007 to present=== [[File:Jenkem1.jpg|thumb|The Collier County Sheriff Office intelligence bulletin from September 26, 2007 which was later leaked to the media.]] On September 26, 2007, the Sheriff's Department of [[Collier County, Florida]] issued an internal bulletin about jenkem based on a [[TOTSE]] internet forum post by user "Pickwick", which included purported photos of the manufacture and use. "Pickwick" confessed it was a hoax around the time of the internal bulletin.{{cite web |url=http://www.totse.com/community/showthread.php?t=2055429 |title=The jenkem thing was a hoax |last=pickwick |work=TOTSE |publisher=totse.com |accessdate=17 September 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080728042704/http://www.totse.com/community/showthread.php?t=2055429 |archivedate=2008-07-28}} In November of that year, officials at the [[Drug Enforcement Administration]] said no reports of jenkem use had been confirmed in the United States.{{cite news |last=Goldman |first=Russell |title='Jenkem': Stay Alert or Call It a Hoax? |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Health/Drugs/Story?id=3834092&page=1 |format= |publisher=[[ABC News]] |date=November 7, 2007 |accessdate=2007-11-08}} After initially classifying stories of Western jenkem use as "undetermined", [[Snopes]] quickly reclassified it as "false". [[About.com]] also concluded reports were "based on faulty [[Internet research]]". [[The Smoking Gun]] stated the Collier County alert "may be full of shit".{{cite web |url=http://www.thesmokinggun.com/archive/years/2007/1105072jenkem1.html |title=NewDrugAlert!-Nov5.2007 |work= |accessdate=}} Drug research site [[Erowid]] reported, "the jenkem stories that have been circulating in the U.S. media are almost certainly the strange result of a hoax."Vaults of Erowid (November 2007). [http://www.erowid.org/ask/ask.php?ID=3113 Ask Erowid: ID 3113.] Retrieved December 30, 2007. Jenkem use was reported uncritically by [[KIMT]] of [[Mason City, Iowa]],{{cite news |first=Erin |last=Therese |title=Dirty New Drug Threatens Youth |url=http://www.kimt.com/news/local/10984491.html |work=KIMT.com |publisher=[[KIMT|KIMT-TV]] |date=November 3, 2007 |accessdate=2007-11-04 |language= |quote= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071214031134/http://www.kimt.com/news/local/10984491.html |archivedate=2007-12-14 }} [[WIFR-TV]] in [[Rockford, Illinois]],{{cite news|first= |last= |title=Disturbing New Drug Teens Are Using |url=http://www.wifr.com/news/headlines/11064316.html |work=WIFR.com |publisher=[[WIFR|WIFR-TV]], Rockford, Illinois |date=November 6, 2007 |accessdate=2007-11-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071217122331/http://www.wifr.com/news/headlines/11064316.html |archivedate=December 17, 2007 |df= }} and [[WINK-TV#News operation|WINK NEWS]] [[Fort Myers, Florida]].{{cite news|first= |last= |authorlink= |author= |coauthors= |title=ONLY ON WINK: Are local kids using human waste to get high? |url=http://www.winknews.com/news/local/10987146.html |work=WINK NEWS.com |publisher=[[WINK-TV#News operation|WINK NEWS]] |date=November 3, 2007 |accessdate=2007-11-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071104200613/http://www.winknews.com/news/local/10987146.html |archivedate=November 4, 2007 |df= }} ''[[Washington Post]]'' columnist Emil Steiner reported that "a spokesman for the [[Drug Enforcement Administration]] insists that 'there are people in America trying [jenkem],'" which the DEA agent characterized as "dangerous, bad and stupid."{{cite news |first=Emil |last=Steiner |authorlink=Emil Steiner |title=Jenkem Madness? – Reports of a Nasty Drug in Florida |url=http://blog.washingtonpost.com/offbeat/2007/11/jenkem_madness_1.html |work=OFF/beat blog |publisher=[[The Washington Post]] |date=November 6, 2007 |accessdate=2007-11-06 |language= |quote= }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}} [[Fox News Channel|Fox News]] ran the story after the Steiner ''Washington Post'' column, mentioning Pickwick's hoax and retraction.{{cite news |title='Drug' Made From Human Waste Causing Stink on Web, in Law Enforcement |url= http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,308841,00.html |work=[[Fox News Channel]] |publisher=[[Fox News Channel]] |date=November 6, 2007 |accessdate=2007-11-07}} In the same article, a Washington D.C. DEA spokesman, Garrison Courtney, specified that, "We wouldn't classify it as a drug so much because it's feces and urine." UK technology tabloid website ''[[The Register]]'' concluded that "the jury's out."{{cite news |first=Lester |last=Haines |authorlink= |title=Florida cops issue shock 'Butthash' warning |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2007/11/06/jenkem_warning/ |format= |publisher=''[[The Register]]'' |date=November 6, 2007 |accessdate=2007-11-13}} [[ABC News]] interviewed DEA spokesman Garrison Courtney, who stated that, "It is in Africa, we know that... We've heard rumors and speculation about it here, but part of looking for trends is listening first for speculation. It is something we want to keep on top of." [[WSBT-TV]] in [[South Bend, Indiana|South Bend]], [[Indiana]] advised parents to "wait up for [their children] at night and not let their kids go to bed until they have seen them and smelled their breath."{{cite news |last=Cheatham |first=Kelli |title=Police Warn About New Drug Made from Raw Sewage |url=http://www.wsbt.com/news/11077771.html |work=WSBT.com |publisher=[[WSBT-TV|WSBT-NEWS]] |date=November 7, 2007 |accessdate=2007-11-07 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071109120038/http://www.wsbt.com/news/11077771.html |archivedate=2007-11-09}} [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], Texas NBC affiliate [[KXAN-TV]] interviewed a local teen, whose parent speculated on its use: "Once it becomes OK with a certain group of adolescents, it becomes OK with a lot more."{{cite news |title=Police Training On How To Spot Nasty Drug |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/21684383/ |format= |work=msnbc.com |publisher=[[KXAN-TV]] |date=November 7, 2007 |accessdate=2007-11-08 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071112023107/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/21684383/ |archivedate=2007-11-12}} [[Australia]]n broadcaster [[ninemsn]] summarized American news reports.{{cite news |title='Poop gas drug' prompts official warning |url=http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=318897 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071110153029/http://news.ninemsn.com.au/article.aspx?id=318897 |publisher=[[ninemsn]] |date=November 8, 2007 |accessdate=2015-03-11 |deadurl=yes |archivedate=2007-11-10}} A syndicated report published on the web pages of [[Columbia Broadcasting System|CBS]] affiliate [[WJAX-TV|CBS-47]] and [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] affiliate [[WFOX-TV|Fox 30]], both in [[Jacksonville]], Florida, reported on jenkem and also referred to it by the slang term "''butt hash''", citing media reports from the ''Washington Post'', the [[Drudge Report]], and [[Inside Edition]]. This was also followed up by a Fox 30 televised news segment, in which Captain Tim Guerrette of the Collier County Sheriff's department was interviewed.{{cite news |last=Westerman |first=Brandon |title=Police warn teens using new human waste drug "Jenkem" |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071229105522/http://www.cbs47.com/content/topstories/story.aspx?content_id=7756e4b4-e7db-43cb-b8bb-d5b72111f816&rss=1 |url=http://www.cbs47.com/content/topstories/story.aspx?content_id=7756e4b4-e7db-43cb-b8bb-d5b72111f816&rss=1 |publisher=[[WJAX-TV|CBS-47]] |date=November 8, 2007 |accessdate=2016-11-05 |deadurl=yes |archivedate=2007-12-29}} A Florida syndicated newspaper article focused on the leaked police memo and included interviews with DEA spokesman Rusty Payne, the [[Palmetto Ridge High School]] principal, and a spokeswoman for the Collier County Health Department.{{cite news |last=Mills |first=Ryan |title=Sheriff’s Office warns of new human waste drug, others pooh-pooh its existence |url=http://www.bonitanews.com/news/2007/nov/08/sheriffs_office_warns_new_human_waste_drug_others_/?latest |format= |work=bonitanews.com |publisher=''Bonita Daily News'' |date=November 8, 2007 |accessdate=2007-11-08}}
{{cite news |last=Mills |first=Ryan |title=Sheriff’s Office warns of new human waste drug, others pooh-pooh its existence |url=http://www.naplesnews.com/news/2007/nov/08/sheriffs_office_warns_new_human_waste_drug_others_/? |format= |work=naplesnews.com |publisher=''Naples Daily News'' |date=November 8, 2007 |accessdate=2007-11-08}} Jamie Pietras of [[Salon.com]] published a long piece on jenkem in 2007. Pietras interviewed a Zambian government official on ways to curtail use and also focused on the Western [[moral panic|media scare]]. Pietras interviewed researcher Earth Erowid of [[Erowid]], and Jag Davies, the communications director for the [[Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies]] (MAPS), neither of whom could provide any confirmation of its use in America. [[Partnership for a Drug-Free America]] public affairs representative Candice Besson also stated that PDFA had not previously heard about the drug. ''The Enterprise Ledger'' of [[Enterprise, Alabama]] quoted a local narcotics investigator who believed it was being used in [[Coffee County, Alabama]].{{cite news |last=Brand |first=Carole |title=New drug in use by high school students |url=http://www.eprisenow.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=ENT/MGArticle/ENT_BasicArticle&c=MGArticle&cid=1173353435258&path=!news |format= |publisher=''The Enterprise Ledger'' |date=November 9, 2007 |accessdate=2007-11-09}} A commentary in ''The Times-Reporter'' of [[Dover, Ohio|Dover]]-[[New Philadelphia, Ohio|New Philadelphia]], Ohio said jenkem was "largely debunked", but that "someone will be stupid enough to try it."{{cite news|author=Blundo, Noah |title=Federal government attempts to wipe clean smelly drug world |url=http://www.timesreporter.com/index.php?ID=75258 |publisher=''The Times-Reporter'' |date=November 11, 2007 |accessdate=2007-11-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071124051533/http://www.timesreporter.com/index.php?ID=75258 |archivedate=November 24, 2007 |df= }} The story was also covered with varying degrees of skepticism in ''[[The Orange County Register]]'',{{cite news |author= |title=They’re getting high HOW? |url=http://www.ocregister.com/ocregister/life/abox/article_1920782.php |publisher=''[[The Orange County Register]]'' |date=November 13, 2007 |accessdate=2007-11-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071116124701/http://www.ocregister.com/ocregister/life/abox/article_1920782.php |archivedate=November 16, 2007 |df= }} [[Evansville, Indiana]] [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] affiliate [[WTVW]],{{cite news|author= |title=Human Waste High? |url=http://tristatehomepage.com/content/fulltext/?cid=3398 |publisher=''[[WTVW]]'' |date=November 13, 2007 |accessdate=2007-11-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071218150456/http://tristatehomepage.com/content/fulltext/?cid=3398 |archivedate=December 18, 2007 }} and [[Wichita, Kansas]] [[CBS]] affiliate [[KWCH-TV]].{{cite news |author=Wilhelm, Kim |title=No Actual Cases of Kids Sniffing Raw Sewage |url=http://www.kbsd6.com/Global/story.asp?S=7349741 |publisher=''[[KWCH-DT|KWCH]]'' |date=November 13, 2007 |accessdate=2007-11-13 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071116132453/http://www.kbsd6.com/Global/story.asp?S=7349741 |archivedate=2007-11-16}} In 2009, [[Bettendorf, Iowa]] amended its [[city ordinance]] regarding illegal inhalants to include [[organic substance|organic]] substances.{{Cite news |last=Heitz |first=David |title=Bettendorf prepares to expand huffing ordinance |url=http://www.qctimes.com/news/local/article_d3d96d82-9b5a-11de-81bb-001cc4c002e0.html |work=[[Quad-City Times]] |location=[[Davenport, Iowa]] |date=September 7, 2009 |accessdate=September 8, 2009}}{{Cite news |author= |title=Bettendorf strengthens huffing ordinance |url=http://www.qctimes.com/news/local/article_c550c682-b34e-11de-9320-001cc4c03286.html |work=Quad-City Times |location=Davenport, Iowa |date=October 7, 2009 |accessdate=October 8, 2009}} In 2010, an apartment building in [[Fort Pierce, Florida]] was condemned after police found leaking containers of human waste in a unit. One police official speculated the tenant was manufacturing jenkem.{{Cite news|last=Scofield |first=Carolyn |title=Smelly house forces tenants to leave |url=http://www.wptv.com/dpp/news/region_st_lucie_county/fort_pierce/smelly-house-forces-tenants-to-leave |work=[[WPTV-TV]] |date=December 3, 2010 |accessdate=December 5, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101208060926/http://www.wptv.com/dpp/news/region_st_lucie_county/fort_pierce/smelly-house-forces-tenants-to-leave |archivedate=December 8, 2010 |df= }}{{Cite news |last=Fitzgerald |first=Scott |title=Waste-Filled Apartment Causes a Stink |url=http://www.nbcmiami.com/news/local-beat/wastedapt-111274134.html |work=[[NBC Miami]] |date=December 3, 2010 |accessdate=December 5, 2010}} ==See also== *[[Bananadine]] *[[Deviancy amplification spiral]] *[[Psychoactive toad]] *[[Whoonga]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{wiktionary|jenkem}} *[http://www.snopes.com/crime/warnings/jenkem.asp Jenkem] via [[Snopes.com]] [[Category:Inhalants]] [[Category:Dissociative drugs]] [[Category:Feces]] [[Category:Hoaxes about drugs]] [[Category:Zambian society]] [[Category:Zambian culture]]

page.title: Julie and Carol at Lincoln Center

revision.text:
{{Infobox television | show_name = Julie and Carol at Lincoln Center | image = | caption = | writer = [[Bob Ellison]]
Marty Farrell
Mitzie Welch | director = [[Dave Powers (director)|Dave Powers]] | starring = [[Julie Andrews]]
[[Carol Burnett]] | music = [[Peter Matz]] | country = United States | language = English | producer = [[Joe Hamilton (producer)|Joe Hamilton]] | runtime = 60 minutes | company = | distributor = | network = [[CBS]] | first_aired = {{Start date|1971|12|7}} | followed_by = ''[[Julie & Carol: Together Again]]'' | website = }} '''''Julie and Carol at Lincoln Center''''' is a 1971 American [[television special]] featuring [[Julie Andrews]] and [[Carol Burnett]], their second out of three specials after ''[[Julie and Carol at Carnegie Hall]]'' (1962) and before ''[[Julie & Carol: Together Again]]'' (1989). Held at the [[David Geffen Hall|Philharmonic Hall]] at [[Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts|Lincoln Center]] in [[New York City]], it was produced by [[Joe Hamilton (producer)|Joe Hamilton]],{{Cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Julie-Andrews-And-Carol-Burnett-Julie-And-Carol-At-Lincoln-Center/release/3816959|title=Julie Andrews And Carol Burnett - Julie And Carol At Lincoln Center|website=Discogs|language=en|access-date=2017-05-10}} and written by [[Bob Ellison]], Marty Farrell and Mitzi Welch, who reused the template from the first show.{{Cite news|url=http://www.masterworksbroadway.com/blog/julie-and-carol-so-nice-they-did-it-twice/|title=Julie and Carol: So Nice, They Did It Twice {{!}} The Official Masterworks Broadway Site|date=2012-04-10|work=The Official Masterworks Broadway Site|access-date=2017-05-10|language=en-US}} == Setlist == {| class="wikitable" |1 |Our Classy Classical Show |- |2 |Girls In The Band |- |3 |Madame Abernall's (I Could Have Danced All Night) |- |4 |He's Gone Away |- |5 |Medley Of The 60's |- |6 |Wait Till The Sun Shines Nellie |- |7 |Finale |} As with the previous concert, the two comedian singers performed a medley; this one 14 minutes long and celebrating music of the 60's. == Critical reception and analysis == {{Quote|text=The audience was not watching two supertalented singing actresses cutting up and making fun at the country's premier temple of culture; they were watching two beloved icons trying — or perhaps pretending to try — to cut up.|sign=Playbill|source={{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/on-the-record-julie-and-carol-and-liza-live-plus-a-re-listen-to-maury-yestons-titanic-com-192597|title=ON THE RECORD: Julie and Carol and Liza, Live; Plus a Re-Listen to Maury Yeston's Titanic - Playbill|website=Playbill}}}} The official website of [[Carnegie Hall]] asserted that this reprise of the Carnegie Hall concert confirmed that Julie and Carol had achieved a level of fame, success, and double-act after their 1962 show.{{Cite web|url=https://www.carnegiehall.org/BlogPost.aspx?id=4294987248|title=Celebrating 50 Years of Julie and Carol at Carnegie Hall: Part 2|website=www.carnegiehall.org|access-date=2017-05-10}} Playbill lamented that this show tried to mimic its predecessor.{{Cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/on-the-record-julie-and-carol-and-liza-live-plus-a-re-listen-to-maury-yestons-titanic-com-192597|title=ON THE RECORD: Julie and Carol and Liza, Live; Plus a Re-Listen to Maury Yeston's Titanic {{!}} Playbill|website=Playbill|language=en|access-date=2017-05-10}} Denton Record-Chronicle deemed the special "renowned".{{Cite news|url=http://www.dentonrc.com/entertainment/movies/2015/09/05/dvd-reviews-remember-the-alamo|title=DVD reviews: Remember the Alamo? {{!}} Movies {{!}} Denton Record-Chronicle|date=2015-09-05|work=Denton Record-Chronicle|access-date=2017-05-10|language=en}} The show was nominated for the 1972 Emmy for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Variety, Music, or Comedy Special|Outstanding Single Program – Variety or Musical – Variety and Popular Music]]. == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:1971 television specials]] [[Category:1970s American television specials]] [[Category:Music television specials]] [[Category:CBS television specials]]

{{more footnotes|date=January 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}} [[Image:Katastrofa hali Katowice, 2006.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Hall after collapse.]] On 28 January 2006, the roof of one of the buildings at the [[Katowice International Fair]] (''Międzynarodowe Targi Katowickie'') collapsed in [[Chorzów]] / [[Katowice]], Poland<!---[[Chorzów]] (land buildings) and [[Katowice]] (address and main street to KIF)--->.
At 16:15 GMT (17:15 local time), the central section of the roof of the hall collapsed, possibly due to the weight of snow on the building. According to the [[Policja|police]] there were roughly 700 people in the hall at the time of the collapse. A further collapse occurred 90 minutes later during rescue operations. [[Polish government]] spokesman [[Krzysztof Mejer]] confirmed that there had been 65 dead as well as more than 170 injured, including 13 foreigners. There are confirmed deaths of ten foreign tourists – one from [[Belgium]], one from Germany, three from [[Slovakia]], one from the [[Netherlands]], one from [[Hungary]] and three from the [[Czech Republic]]. The trade hall was hosting the 56th National Exhibition of [[Carrier Pigeon]]s, with over 120 exhibitors from all over Europe. Poland was at that time experiencing very cold weather with heavy snow. This meant that the [[rescue]] operation was undertaken in sub-zero temperatures, putting the survivors inside the building at risk of exposure.
==Rescue operation== Rescue support was sent from the surrounding area, including Katowice, as well as from the neighbouring province of [[Lesser Poland]]. Since parts of the collapsed structure were supported only by heaps of snow, the rescue teams could not heat the pockets beneath the collapsed roof with hot air, fearing that the roof might collapse even further.
The [[search and rescue]] action was terminated on the afternoon of Sunday 29 January 2006 as, according to [[Janusz Skulich]], commander of the [[Silesia]]n Fire Fighters, the probability of rescuing any more survivors from beneath the collapsed roof was by then close to zero. Heavy equipment is reported to have started clearing the area of the remaining rubble.
The rescue action was carried out by 103 firefighter teams (more than 1000 fire fighters altogether), [[Emergency medical services in Poland|EMS]] units as well as 230 policemen with dogs, military police units from [[Kraków]] and [[Gliwice]], the [[GOPR]] [[mountain rescue]] team of [[Szczyrk]] and specialists from the [[mine rescue]] team of [[Bytom]]. Survivors were taken to nearby hospitals in [[Chorzów]] and [[Katowice]], and to other towns of the region, including [[Siemianowice Śląskie]], [[Bytom]], [[Sosnowiec]], [[Ruda Śląska]], [[Dąbrowa Górnicza]] and [[Piekary Śląskie]]. [[Andrzej Skrzyś]], vice-president of [[Polish Society of Carrier-Pigeons]] said that by Saturday the rescue services had brought over 1,000 pigeons to the office of the society, that were being fed and watered by pigeon-fanciers from Chorzów until the arrival of their owners.
On 30 January 2006 there were 67 confirmed deaths and about 30 missing people. Later that day the number of victims was revised down to 62 confirmed deaths.<ref>{{cite news|title=Poland cuts death toll from cave-inof roof to 62|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/30/world/europe/30iht-poland.html|work=New York Times|accessdate=5 November 2012}}</ref> On 31 January three more bodies were found in the ruins of MTK, raising the death toll to 65. Next day, officials stated that due to irregularities by funeral houses and dissection rooms, the wrong number of victims had been reported, and on 1 February there were 63 confirmed deaths. On 11 and 14 February the bodies of the 64th and 65th victims of roof collapse were found.
In the morning of 19 February workers got to the last area of the hall that was still covered by fragments of the hall’s collapsed roof. They found no more victims but found two pigeons that were still alive after spending 22 days trapped under the rubble.
==Aftermath and investigation== After the tragedy, senior authorities arrived at the scene, including the Prime Minister [[Kazimierz Marcinkiewicz]] and the President of Poland [[Lech Kaczyński]]. The latter declared the period until 1 February to be [[National day of mourning|national days of mourning]].
On Tuesday, 21 February, at 0600 hours Central European Time (0500 UTC) three people were arrested and brought to the Katowice District Prosecutor’s Office: New Zealand–born chairman of the International Katowice Fair Board of Management Bruce Robinson (who was also a Managing Director of the London–based Expomedia company that owned a 51% share in MTK), deputy chairman Ryszard Ziółek, and the company’s technical manager Adam Hildebrandt. They were interviewed and charged with criminal negligence – allegedly they were aware of the fact that the building was unsafe and yet allowed the Fair to go on, and by doing so they contributed to deaths of 65 people. The spokesperson for the Prosecutor’s Office did not rule out laying other charges in the future – depending on facts established by experts on causes of the building’s collapse. A search warrant was also executed at Mr. Robinson’s Warsaw apartment. The charges carried a maximum of 8 years imprisonment. Prosecutors also applied to the court for the accused to be detained for 3 months. The application was granted by the court, their application for bail was refused. A judge is quoted as saying that immediately after the catastrophe the accused destroyed some vital documents and there exists a possibility that if they were released on bail they would intimidate witnesses to change their testimonies. Their appeal against arrest was rejected by the District Court on 5 May.
After interviewing some 200 witnesses, the analysis of company documents, experts’ findings and data from the company’s computers (some of which was recovered by computer specialists) the prosecutors allege that the accused were responsible for failing to remove heavy snow and ice from the building’s roof, and also that in the past, the roof had gotten damaged and yet they carried out only emergency repairs and did not report the damage to a building inspector as required by Polish law. Earlier the managers claimed both that the snow was removed from the roof and that it was impossible for them to clear the roof because a Tax Office seized their accounts due to tax arrears. A spokesperson for the Tax Office refuted this claim saying that only some of the company’s cash was seized and amounts remaining should have been more than sufficient to pay for snow and ice removal.
On 31 March 2006 the commission investigating causes of the disaster released a preliminary report into their findings. They found numerous design and construction flaws that contributed to the speed of the collapse. The snow from the roof was not being removed which resulted in construction overload by more than 100%. Moreover, in 2002 the construction buckled under the heavy snow; contrary to the regulations the hall was repaired without getting a building inspector’s clearance and without doing necessary tests and calculations to determine if the construction was stable and had sufficient strength.
On Monday, 26 June 2006, three architects who designed the hall were arrested. Two were charged with "wilfully causing a building catastrophe" and by this causing the death of 65 people, the third one was charged with "involuntarily causing a building catastrophe." The prosecutor alleges that Jacek J. and Szczepan K. made several errors and introduced several amendments to the project that were not agreed upon. Both were aware of the fact that in January 2000 the roof buckled under the weight of the snow, yet they did not take any steps to remedy the situation and perhaps prevent the tragedy. The third architect, Andrzej W., is charged with approving the project despite its errors and deficiencies. The charges are the result of reports made by experts on building, steel constructions and reinforced concrete constructions. Pursuant to Polish law that automatically grants the accused name suppression, the surnames of the accused are unavailable in the Polish media.
On 14 February 2007 the Court of Appeal in Katowice granted bail to the three top bosses of the company – Bruce Robinson, Ryszard Ziółek, and Adam Hildebrandt. Mr. Robinson had to pay a 100,000 zloty bond (approx. €25,000/$33,000/£17,000), and the other two – 50,000 zloty each. All three also had to remain under police supervision and had to surrender their passports. The prosecutor appealed against granting of bail while one of the accused appealed against the amount. On Monday, the 5 March 2007, the Court of Appeal in Katowice rejected both appeals and at the same time raised the amount that Bruce Robinson has to deposit to 300,000 zloty (about €75,000/$100,000/£50,000). The ruling was final.
As a result of the catastrophe, in March 2007 Polish building law was amended. Large buildings must now undergo a technical survey twice every year (before and after winter) to make sure they are safe and structurally sound. Failure to conduct the survey is punishable by a minimum 1,000 zloty fine or a term in prison.
==Indictment and trial==
The investigation was formally completed at the end of June 2008. The public prosecutor of the Katowice District Public Prosecutor’s Office decided to indict 12 people. These include the designers of the hall, Jacek J. and Szczepan K., who on conviction for “directly endangering lives of other people” faced up to 12 years of prison, two members of the board, Bruce Robinson and Ryszard Ziółek, and 7 other people, who if convicted for gross negligence would face up to 8 years in jail, and the Chorzów County building inspector who faced lesser charges. The indictment was filed with the court on 18 July.
The experts determined that the main reason for the catastrophe was incorrect design. It was changed in order to make the construction cheaper. Emails recovered from seized computers proved that members of the Board of Directors were fully aware of the problems and of an expert’s recommendation that snow be removed from the roof and that the design was verified. One of the indicted, technical coordinator Piotr I., was charged with failing to order the evacuation doors to be opened; he is the only one that pleaded guilty. In the course of the investigation it was found that none of the victims died because of locked evacuation doors.
Post-mortems carried out on victims have shown that none of them died of exposure; all died because of injuries sustained because of the collapse of the roof.
==Location of MTK== There has been some confusion over whether MTK is located in Katowice or Chorzów. The registered and street addresses of the company are in Katowice, and the entrance to the grounds is from a street that belongs administratively to Katowice. However, the company’s grounds—and thus the site of the catastrophe—lie within Chorzów’s administrative boundaries. <ref>{{pl icon}} [http://www.chorzow.um.gov.pl/index.php4?ID=113848898720415286 official explanation and map of the Katowice-Chorzów boundary]</ref>
==Nationalities of the victims== [[Image:MTK pomnik.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Memorial to the collapse victims in Katowice.]] {|class="wikitable" |- style="background:#ccf;" !|Nationality|||Victims |- valign=top |{{flagcountry|Poland}}||55 |- valign=top |{{flagcountry|Czech Republic}}||3 |- valign=top |{{flagcountry|Slovakia}}||3 |- valign=top |{{flagcountry|Belgium|state}}||1 |- valign=top |{{flagcountry|Germany}}||1 |- valign=top |{{flagcountry|Hungary}}||1 |- valign=top |{{flagcountry|Netherlands}}||1 |- valign=top |'''Total'''||'''65''' |}

{{globalize|list|the English-speaking world|date=November 2016}} This is a '''list of close [[election]] results''' at [[Nation-state|national]] and [[State (administrative division)|state]] level. It lists results that have been decided by a margin of less than 1 vote in 1000 (a margin of victory of less than 0.1%). To provide context, after the first table is another table showing the distribution of winning margins in different areas. Depending on the area, from 1 in 40 to 1 in 500 election contests is decided by less than 1 vote in 1000. This list is limited to elections in which at least 1000 votes were cast. According to a 2001 study of state and federal elections in the United States between 1898 and 1992, "one of every 100,000 votes cast in U.S. elections, and one of every 15,000 votes cast in state elections, "mattered" in the sense that they were cast for a candidate that officially tied or won by one vote." While not an election, a member of Congress once owed his seat to the drawing of lots. In 1902, after more than 7000 votes at three conventions, the Democrats were unable to decide among three candidates for nomination to [[Texas's 12th congressional district]]. Two candidates put their names in a hat, drew one out and the loser agreed to withdraw and support the winner. [[Oscar W. Gillespie]] won the game of lots, the nomination and the following general election, serving in Congress for 8 years.{{cite news|title=Gillespie is Nominated|url=https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86090049/1902-09-10/ed-1/seq-2.pdf|accessdate=27 December 2017|work=The San Angelo Press|date=10 September 1902}} There are a variety of ways in which tied elections are settled. Some are decided by drawing lots or other games of chances. Others lead to a runoff or special election. Still others are decided by some third party such as the legislature or a high-ranking elected official. In one case in [[Crawfordsville, Indiana]], in 1891, it was settled with a 200-yard footrace. In that case William Simms seemed to be cruising to an easy victory for County Treasurer when he tripped and fell 3 yards from the finish line allowing Frank Hollowell to win the race instead.{{cite news|title=Crawled over the Line|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/16439766/|accessdate=11 January 2018|work=The Pensacola News|date=10 May 1891}} ==Table of close national and state elections== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Romano and Widmer, both of the PPD, were tied for the PPD's second seat.) |- | 1994 | {{flagicon|Canada}} {{flagicon|Quebec}} | [[Quebec general election, 1994|Quebec general]] | [[Saint-Jean (provincial electoral district)|Saint-Jean]] | 0% | 0 | {{nts|16536}} | Incumbent [[Quebec Liberal Party|Liberal]] [[Michel Charbonneau]] tied with [[Parti Québécois]] candidate [[Roger Paquin]]. Consequently, a new vote was held 42 days later, which Paquin won by 532 votes.{{cite web|url=http://www.quebecpolitique.com/elections-et-referendums/circonscriptions/elections-dans-saint-jean/ |title=Election results in Saint-Jean |publisher=Quebecpolitique.com |date= |accessdate=June 4, 2010}} |- |1971 |{{flagicon|USA}} {{flagicon|Virginia}} |[[Virginia House of Delegates]] |District 19 |0% |0 |16,410 |The initial vote count had [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] William Moss ahead of Democrat Jim Burch by 1 vote for the sixth at-large seat in what was then a six-member district. But then a three-judge circuit court ruled that one of the ballots was "defaced" because the names of two candidates were crossed out with the notation "Do not desire to vote for these two". They did this even though the person who cast this vote (which was known because it was a signed absentee ballot) testified that he intended to vote for Moss. Throwing out the ballot created a tied vote.{{cite news|last1=Whitaker|first1=Joseph|title=Youth, 18, Says He Cast Vote That, Thrown Out, Tied Race|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/retropolis/wp/2017/12/31/elections-gone-wild-the-teen-who-messed-up-his-absentee-ballot-creating-va-s-last-tied-race/|accessdate=5 January 2018|work=Washington Post|date=25 December 1971}} The names of the two candidates were placed in sealed envelopes, and a blindfolded Elections Board chairman plucked one from a silver [[Loving cup|loving cup]]. Moss won.{{cite news|last1=Vozella|first1=Laura|title=The teen who messed up his absentee ballot, creating Virginia's previous tied race|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/retropolis/wp/2017/12/31/elections-gone-wild-the-teen-who-messed-up-his-absentee-ballot-creating-va-s-last-tied-race/|accessdate=5 January 2018|work=Washington Post|date=31 December 2017}} Two years later Moss would lose re-election by 0.03% of the vote.{{cite web|title=1973 House of Delegates General Election District 19|url=http://historical.elections.virginia.gov/elections/view/48555/|accessdate=5 January 2018}} |- | 2003 | {{flagicon|Canada}} {{flagicon|Quebec}} | [[Quebec general election, 2003|Quebec general]] || [[Champlain (provincial electoral district)|Champlain]] | 0% || 0 || {{nts|11852}} | PQ candidate [[Noëlla Champagne]] tied with Liberal [[Pierre Brouillette]]. December 2017|date=26 December 2017}} On January 4, 2018, the names of each candidate was placed inside a film canister, both canisters were placed in a bowl and one canister was drawn at random by State Board of Elections chairman James Alcorn. David Yancey won the draw and the seat, giving Republicans control of the House 51-49.{{cite news|last1=McCammon|first1=Sarah|title=Virginia Republican David Yancey Wins Tie-Breaking Drawing|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/01/04/573504079/virginia-republican-david-yancey-wins-tie-breaking-drawing|accessdate=4 January 2018|date=4 January 2018}} Control of this single seat determined whether Republicans controlled the House of Delegates or if power was evenly split.{{cite news|last1=O'Connor|first1=Lydia|title=Shelly Simonds Concedes To David Yancey In Virginia Tiebreaker Race|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/shelly-simonds-concedes_us_5a564239e4b03417e8743f7f|accessdate=10 January 2018|work=Huffington Post|date=10 January 2018}} |- |2010 |{{flagicon|USA}} {{flagicon|Massachusetts}} |[[Massachusetts general election, 2010|Massachusetts House of Representatives]] |6th Worcester district |0% |0 |6,587 |After Peter J. McIntyre and Dick Casey; and, Republicans Hal Wick and Judy Rost were contesting two seats. In the initial tally, they had respectively 4195 (24.73%), 3889 (22.93%), 4191 (24.71%), and 4687 (27.63%) votes (16,962 total votes). McIntyre was initially declared to have been elected by a four-vote margin. Wick petitioned for a recount in accordance with SDCL 12-21-12. The recount was conducted in the presence of representatives for both candidates. The results were certified on December 4, 1996, and showed that Wick had been elected by one vote: 4191 (24.71%), 3891 (22.94%), 4192 (24.71%), 4689 (27.64%) (16,963 total votes). The [[South Dakota Supreme Court]] examined several ballots and invalidated one vote for Wick. The House then voted, mostly along party lines, 46–20 to seat Wick.{{Cite web|url=http://ujs.sd.gov/Supreme_Court/opiniondetail.aspx?ID=947|title=Opinion|website=ujs.sd.gov|access-date=2017-07-15}}{{Cite web|url=https://sdsos.gov/elections-voting/election-resources/election-history/1996/1996_general_election_returns_legislative_races.aspx|title=Election Resources: South Dakota Secretary of State, Shantel Krebs|website=sdsos.gov|access-date=2017-07-15}} Remarkably, two years later, McIntyre and Wick would again tie (at least on the initial count). |- | 1999 || {{flagicon|Canada}} {{flagicon|Nova Scotia}} |style="white-space: nowrap"| [[Nova Scotia general election, 1999|Nova Scotia general]] || [[Shelburne (provincial electoral district)|Shelburne]] | 0% || 0 || 3,206 | Progressive Conservative [[Cecil O'Donnell]] tied with Liberal [[Clifford Huskilson]] (3,206–3,206).{{Cite web|url=http://electionsnovascotia.ca/sites/default/files/99SHELBU.pdf|title=Shelburne, Nova Scotia, 1999|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} The returning officer broke the tie by pulling Mr. O'Donnell's name from a box.{{Cite web|url=http://www.herald.ns.ca/cgi-bin/home/displaypackstory?1999%2F08%2F18+191.raw+PE99Aug18+2|title=Tories pull one out|date=2005-01-24|access-date=2017-06-26|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050124075636/http://www.herald.ns.ca/cgi-bin/home/displaypackstory?1999%2F08%2F18+191.raw+PE99Aug18+2|archivedate=2005-01-24|df=}} |- | 1886 || {{flagicon|UK}} | [[United Kingdom general election, 1886|UK general]] || [[Ashton-under-Lyne (UK Parliament constituency)|Ashton-under-Lyne]] | 0% || 0 || 3,049 | Conservative incumbent [[John Edmund Wentworth Addison]] and Liberal challenger (and English cricketer{{Cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Lancashire/Articles/1/1499.html|title=Lancashire player number 8 – Rowley, Alexander Butler|website=cricketarchive.com|access-date=2017-07-17}}) [[Alexander Rowley|Alexander Butler Rowley]] were tied 3049–3049. A coin toss was held and Studdard won.{{cite news |last1=Hayes |first1=Dixon |title=Coin toss decides Al election, for now |url=http://www.wbrc.com/2018/11/13/coin-toss-decides-clay-co-election-now/ |accessdate=27 November 2018}} A recount the next day turned up one more vote for each and the coin toss stood.{{cite news |last1=Stansell |first1=Ray |title=Recount Finds Two Votes; 2681 Vote Tie |url=http://www.claytimesjournal.com/news/2018-11-22/Front_Page/Recount_Finds_Two_Votes_2681_Vote_Tie.html |accessdate=27 November 2018 |work=Clay Times Journal}} |- | 1980 | {{flagicon|USA}} {{flagicon|New Hampshire}} | [[New Hampshire State Senate|New Hampshire State Senate Republican Primary]] | District 16 | 0% | 0 | 2,438 | Incumbent Frank Wageman found himself in a tied election after a hospitalization left him unable to vote in the election. The deciding vote in Davin's favor was cast by the returning officer after the two candidates tied.{{cite web|url=http://www2.parl.gc.ca/Sites/LOP/HFER/hfer.asp?genElection=8&Language=E&Search=Gres&ridProvince=0&submit1=Search |title=Parliament of Canada: History of Federal Ridings: General Elections: 8th Parliament |publisher=.parl.gc.ca |date= |accessdate=June 4, 2010}} |- |2015 |{{flagicon|Canada}} |[[Prince Edward Island general election, 2015|Prince Edward Island Provincial General Election]] |[[Vernon River-Stratford]] |0% |0 |1,173 |On Declaration Day, Mary Ellen McInnis and Alan McIsaac had 1,172–1,174 votes. McInnis filed a petition for a judicial recount. Provincial Court Judge John Douglas discovered that a vote for Ms. McInnis was mistakenly put in the pile for Mr. McIsaac. The result of the recount was thus that they were tied 1,173–1,173. Pursuant to section 102 of the Election Act, the toss of a coin was completed by the Returning Officer. The results of the coin toss were in favour of Alan McIsaac.{{Cite web|url=http://www.assembly.pe.ca/photos/original/elec_CEOrpt2015.pdf|title=2015 Report from the Chief Electoral Officer of Prince Edward Island|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/prince-edward-island/liberal-alan-mcisaac-wins-seat-in-coin-toss-after-recount-tie-1.3079433|title=Coin toss decides winner of P.E.I. seat after tie vote|work=CBC News|access-date=2017-06-22}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.pe.ca/news/local/2015/5/13/pc-candidate-mary-ellen-mcinnis-requesti-4144769.html|title=PC candidate Mary Ellen McInnis requesting recount|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-06-22}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.gov.pe.ca/index.php3/newsroom/index.php3?number=news&newsnumber=10198&dept=&lang=E|title=Government of PEI: News Releases|last=Canada|first=Province of Prince Edward Island,|website=www.gov.pe.ca|access-date=2017-06-22}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.pe.ca/opinion/editorials/2015/5/21/simple-coin-toss-almost-trivializes-vern-4154123.html|title=Simple coin toss almost trivializes Vernon River-Stratford election outcome|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-06-22}} |- |1843 |{{flagicon|USA|1837}} {{flagicon|Indiana}} |[[Indiana State Senate]] |[[Switzerland County, Indiana|Switzerland County]] |0% |0 |915 |Daniel Kelso was initially up one vote on David Henry: 917-916. This election was extensively contested. It was alleged that two additional votes had been incorrectly given to Kelso, so that Henry had in fact won 916–915. There was also one fraudulent vote found in favor of Henry, so the Senate Committee concluded that the correct vote was 915–915. But the Committee also found that the county provision in case of a tie (to let county officials decide the winner) was unconstitutional, and so they reported that no legal election had taken place in Switzerland County and neither Henry nor Kelso won.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wd0fAQAAMAAJ|title=Journal of the Senate of the State of Indiana at Their ... Session|last=Senate|first=Indiana General Assembly|date=1844|publisher=State Printer}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.dibblehistory.org/history3.htm|title=Dibble History – Westward, Ho!|website=www.dibblehistory.org|access-date=2017-07-16}} One book{{Cite book|url=http://hdl.handle.net/2027/wu.89072942634|title=History of Dearborn, Ohio and Switzerland Counties, Indiana :from their earliest settlement.|date=1885|publisher=Chicago :}} reports: Switzerland County was represented in the Senate in 1842 by Daniel Kelso; in 1843, 1844 and 1845, by David Henry. Also: "It has been repeated time and again that the annexation of Texas was carried in the United States Senate by one vote; that Edward A. Hannegan, then the United States Senator from Indiana was elected to the Senate by one vote, and that that one vote was given Hannegan by Daniel Kelso, then senator from Switzerland County, who was elected by one majority. "This is an error, for Kelso, when he voted for Hannegan as United States Senator, represented Switzerland County by virtue of a majority of about 150 voters of the county, over Samuel Howard at the August election of 1842. In 1843 David Henry was elected over Kelso by one majority. Kelso contested the election, and the Senate declared that neither was elected, and sent them back to the people for decision, and at the August election, 1844, Henry was elected by a small but decided majority." (An apocryphal story continues to be told, for example by [http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/story?id=121726 ABC News], about a "David Kelso" winning by one vote in an 1844 Indiana Senate election, the one vote being the vote of a dying man whom "David Kelso" once defended.) |- |1998 |{{flagicon|USA}} {{flagicon|Massachusetts}} |[[Massachusetts general election, 1998|Massachusetts House of Representatives Republican Primary]] |13th Hampden |0% |0 |876 |Official election results showed that Matthew Ferri won the primary, garnering three more votes than opponent Rodney Fountain, but a judge later ruled that it was a tie. The Senate at first agreed to seat Wyman, who served the last 3 days of [[Norris Cotton|Noris Cotton's]] term, but began to deliberate again when the new Senate took office. When the Senate deadlocked for months, Durkin agreed to Wyman's proposal for a new election. The Senate declared the seat vacant and the governor appointed Cotton to hold the seat for six weeks until a special election on September 16. Second Edition. [By Nathaniel Hickman.]|last=States|first=United|last2=Hickman|first2=Nathaniel|date=1840|publisher=G. H. Hickman}} |[[Marcus Morton]] and the incumbent [[Whig Party (United States)|Whig]] [[Edward Everett]] received 51,034–50,725 votes respectively, with the remaining 307 votes went to scattering. The constitution of Massachusetts required a candidate to receive a majority of votes cast in order to win the office outright; otherwise, the legislature would have the authority to choose among the leading candidates. Morton exceeded this threshold by just 1 vote (50% of the 102,066 ballots cast), and had he not, the Whig controlled legislature would have been allowed to select the governor. The legislature could successfully deprive Morton of a majority if it disqualified the return from the town of Westfield. There was, moreover, an argument for doing so: the Westfield return was irregular and improper under the laws of the state because the attestation of its authenticity was not under seal. Instead, the return had been sealed first, and only afterward affixed with an attestation from the relevant local official. Despite pressure from partisans to contest this result, Everett refused. In the annals of American history there is not an equivalent example of a candidate in a major statewide election willing to forgo a victory so tantalizingly within reach based on, first, such a narrow margin and, second, such a readily available legal argument for invalidating disputed ballots.https://books.google.com/books?id=zP7DCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT103 |- | 1984 || {{flagicon|USA}} {{flagicon|Indiana}} |[[United States House of Representatives elections, 1984|United States House of Representatives]] | [[Indiana's 8th congressional district|Indiana's 8th District]] | 0.00171% || 4 || 116,645 | Indiana's Secretary of State (a Republican) initially certified Rick McIntyre as the winner by 34 votes, ignoring other recounted tallies that actually showed [[Frank McCloskey]] was in the lead. That amendment ended the three-fifths rule effectively raising the population of states that once had slavery. As a result, South Carolina and other slave states tried to seat extra members of Congress. South Caroline choose two additional congress members during at-large election. In one of those, Johann Peter Martin Epping defeated Lucius W. Wimbush by 61 votes: 71803-71742. But the House refused to seat him and the other at-large winner. "A number of southern states upon readmission claimed that since their slaves were emancipated, they were entitled to larger delegations in the House. Epping's election falls in this category. However, the result was overturned after it was determined that a counting error had cost [[Socialist Party (France)|Socialist Party]] (PS) candidate [[Ramlati Ali]] of victory, winning by 54 votes in the updated count.{{cite news|title=Législatives: erreur de comptage à Mayotte, la candidate PS élue au détriment d'un LR|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-actu/2017/06/19/97001-20170619FILWWW00179-legislatives-erreur-de-comptage-a-mayotte-la-candidate-ps-elue-au-detriment-d-un-lr.php|agency=Agence France-Presse|newspaper=Le Figaro|date=19 June 2017|accessdate=20 November 2017}} A [[Mayotte's 1st constituency by-election, 2018|by-election]] was called after the [[Constitutional Council (France)|constitutional council]] invalidated the election due to irregularities.{{cite news|author=David Ponchelet|title=Le Conseil Constitutionnel annule l'élection de la députée de Mayotte Ramlati Ali|url=https://la1ere.francetvinfo.fr/conseil-constitutionnel-annule-election-depute-mayotte-ramlati-ali-550881.html|publisher=Outre-Mer 1ère|date=19 January 2018|accessdate=19 January 2018}} |- | 2000 || {{flagicon|Canada}} | [[Canadian federal election, 2000|Canadian federal]] || [[Laval Centre]] | 0.07667% || 42 || {{nts|54782}} | Bloc Québécois MP [[Madeleine Dalphond-Guiral]] narrowly edged out Liberal Pierre Lafleur. |- | 2013 || {{flagicon|USA}} {{flagicon|New Jersey}} | [[New Jersey General Assembly]] || [[New Jersey Legislative Districts, 2011 apportionment#District 2|District 2]] | 0.07954% || 40 || {{nts|50288}} | Democrat [[Vince Mazzeo]] defeated incumbent Republican [[John F. President-elect [[Abraham Lincoln|Lincoln]] received only 1,887 votes.''Dave Leip's Atlas of U.S. Presidential Elections'', [http://uselectionatlas.org/RESULTS/state.php?year=1860&fips=51&f=1&off=0&elect=0 1860 Presidential General Election Results – Virginia] |- | 1874 || {{flagicon|Canada}} | [[Canadian federal election, 1874|Canadian federal]] || [[Leeds South]] | 0.09372% || 3 || {{nts|3201}} | Conservative [[David Ford Jones]] beat challenger W. H. Fredenburgh.{{cite web|url=http://www2.parl.gc.ca/Sites/LOP/HFER/hfer.asp?genElection=3&Language=E&Search=Gres&ridProvince=0&submit1=Search |title=Parliament of Canada: History of Federal Ridings: General Elections: 3rd Parliament |publisher=.parl.gc.ca |date= |accessdate=June 4, 2010}} |- | 1962 || {{flagicon|Canada}} | [[Canadian federal election, 1962|Canadian federal]] || [[St. John's West]] | 0.09391% || 24 || {{nts|25557}} | Liberal [[Richard Cashin]] defeated Progressive Conservative incumbent [[William Joseph Browne]].{{cite web|url=http://www2.parl.gc.ca/Sites/LOP/HFER/hfer.asp?genElection=25&Language=E&Search=Gres&ridProvince=0&submit1=Search |title=Parliament of Canada: History of Federal Ridings: General Elections: 25th Parliament |publisher=.parl.gc.ca |date= |accessdate=June 4, 2010}} |- | 2016 || {{flagicon|Taiwan}} | [[Taiwanese general election, 2016|Taiwanese general]] || [[Taoyuan 4th district|Taoyuan legislative district 4]] | 0.09385% || 162 || {{nts|172622}} | [[Kuomintang|KMT]] incumbent Yang Li-Huan claimed edged [[Democratic Progressive Party|DDP]] challenger Cheng Pao-Ching by 30 votes, when latter [[Central Election Commission (Taiwan)|Central Election Commission]] said Cheng won with 169 votes. The recount in 5 days saw Cheng won by 162 votes.{{Cite news|url = http://www.etaiwannews.com/etn/news_content.php?id=2874432|title = Taoyuan vote recount ends in favor of DPP|last = Strong|first = Matthew|date = 2016-01-27|work = |access-date = |via = }} |- | 1884 || {{flagicon|USA}} {{flagicon|New York}} |style="white-space: nowrap"| [[United States presidential election in New York, 1884|United States presidential]] || [[United States presidential elections in New York|New York]] | 0.09844% || 1,149 || {{nts|1167169}} | Democrat [[Grover Cleveland]] edged out Mainer [[James G. Blaine]] to win New York's decisive 36 electoral votes.{{Citation needed|date=February 2009}} |- | 1878 || {{flagicon|Canada}} | [[Canadian federal election, 1878|Canadian federal]] || [[Jacques Cartier (electoral district)|Jacques Cartier]] | 0.09911% || 2 || {{nts|2018}} | Conservative [[Désiré Girouard]] defeated Liberal incumbent [[Rodolphe Laflamme]].{{cite web|url=http://www2.parl.gc.ca/Sites/LOP/HFER/hfer.asp?genElection=4&Language=E&Search=Gres&ridProvince=0&submit1=Search |title=Parliament of Canada: History of Federal Ridings: General Elections: 4th Parliament |publisher=.parl.gc.ca |date= |accessdate=June 4, 2010}} |- | 1921 || {{flagicon|Canada}} | [[Canadian federal election, 1921|Canadian federal]] || [[Calgary West]] | 0.09955% || 16 || {{nts|16073}} | Labour [[Joseph Tweed Shaw]] defeated Conservative [[R. B. Bennett]] who was, at the time, Minister of Justice.{{cite web|url=http://www2.parl.gc.ca/Sites/LOP/HFER/hfer.asp?genElection=14&Language=E&Search=Gres&ridProvince=0&submit1=Search |title=Parliament of Canada: History of Federal Ridings: General Elections: 14th Parliament |publisher=.parl.gc.ca |date=December 16, 1921 |accessdate=June 4, 2010}} |- | 2017 || {{flagicon|France}} | [[French legislative election, 2017|French legislative (2nd round)]] || [[Loire's 1st constituency]] | 0.09972% || 23 || {{nts|23065}} | [[Régis Juanico]] of the [[Socialist Party (France)|Socialist Party]] (PS), a supporter of [[Benoît Hamon]], held onto his seat narrowly against Magalie Viallon, candidate of [[La République En Marche!]] (REM).{{cite news|author=Delphine de Freitas|title=Certains candidats élus avec 8 voix d'écart, focus sur les scrutins les plus serrés|url=https://www.lci.fr/elections/resultats-legislatives-2017-valls-collard-aliot-ces-candidats-elus-avec-moins-de-500-voix-d-ecart-2055907.html|publisher=LCI|date=19 June 2017|accessdate=20 November 2017}} |- |2016 |{{flagicon|USA}} |[[United States House of Representatives elections in Arizona, 2016|Arizona Republican Primary]] |[[Arizona's 5th congressional district|Arizona's 5th District]] |0.000315% |27 |85,595 |On the night of the Republican Primary for the seat being vacated by Congressman [[Matt Salmon]], State Senator [[Andy Biggs]] lead by a total of 16 votes against Republican challenger, [[Christine Jones (businesswoman)|Christine Jones]]. After a recount that lead widened to 27 votes, and Jones conceded the election.{{Cite news|url=https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/09/16/andy-biggs-christine-jones-recount-5th-congressional-district/90436290/|title=Andy Biggs wins recount; Christine Jones concedes|work=azcentral|access-date=2018-06-15|language=en}} |- |2018 |{{flagicon|USA}} {{flagicon|Maryland}} |Democratic Primary for Baltimore County Executive |Baltimore County |0.0306% |17 |27,820{{cite news |last1=Gates |first1=Bill |title=Recount confirms Olszewski Jr. as primary winner |url=https://www.avenuenews.com/news/local/recount-confirms-olszewski-jr-as-primary-winner/article_741b249d-12ec-5064-b1e0-51a66a31e3ce.html |accessdate=8 November 2018 |work=The Avenue News |date=16 July 2018}} |A three-way race between Vicki Almond, Jim Brochin and Johnny Olszewski Jr. ended initially with Olszewski leading by 346 votes on election night.{{cite news |last1=Wood |first1=Pamela |title=Olszewski affirmed as winner of Democratic primary for Baltimore County executive |url=https://www.baltimoresun.com/news/maryland/politics/bs-md-co-recount-results-20180714-story.html |accessdate=8 November 2018 |work=Baltimore Sun |date=14 July 2018}} But after all of the absentee and provisional ballots were counted, that lead was cut to just 9. A recount ensued and the lead ended at 17 votes for Olszewski.https://wtop.com/local-politics-elections-news/2018/07/olszewski-wins-recount-in-baltimore-co-executive-race-by-17-votes/ |- |2013 |{{flagicon|Australia}} |Australian Federal |Western Australia Senate |0.000000741% |1 |1,348,797 |The Australian senate is elected by a series of complex preference deals/ At one point the next party to be eliminated was between the Shooters and Fishers Party and the Australian Christians. The margin was effectively one vote at that point in the count, and depending on which party was ahead either the Labor Party and PUP or the Sports Party and the Greens would have been elected. As the recount was taking place it became apparent that there were some missing ballots, which was greater than the margin, so the election was voided and a re-run was conducted in 2014.{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-11-08/wa-senate-result-came-down-to-just-one-vote/5080162|title=WA Senate result came down to just one vote|date=2013-11-08|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-08-29|language=en-AU}} |- |2016 |{{flagicon|USA}} {{flagicon|Arizona}} |[[County Recorder|Maricopa County Recorder Republican Primary]] |Maricopa County |0.000651% |202 |310,169 |Incumbent Helen Purcell defeated Aaron Flannery for Maricopa County Recorder. Purcell faced significant controversy following Arizona's 2016 presidential primary in which voters faced long wait times to vote due to a significant reduction in polling places from several hundred to 60. Purcell was soundly defeated in the following General Election.{{cite web|title=2016 County Recorder Republican Primary Maricopa County|url=https://recorder.maricopa.gov/electionresults/archivedelectionresults.aspx}} |- |2014 |{{flagicon|AUS}} {{flagicon|Victoria}} |[[Electoral district of Prahran]] |Victoria Legislative Assembly |0.08378% |31 |37,000 |Victoria uses ranked votes. At the second last count the gap between Labor and the Greens was 31 votes. The Greens then defeated the Liberals by 277 in the final count.{{Cite web|url=https://www.vec.vic.gov.au/Results/State2014/distributionPrahranDistrict.html|title=State Election 2014: Prahran District - First Preference Results by District - Victorian Electoral Commission|website=www.vec.vic.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2018-11-19}} |} ==Distribution of elections by winning margin== Close elections not only demonstrate the effect of individual voters, they may reflect extra efforts from candidates or supporters when elections are close.{{Cite journal |last=Eggers |first=Andrew C. |last2=Fowler |first2=Anthony |last3=Hainmueller |first3=Jens |last4=Hall |first4=Andrew B. |last5=Snyder |first5=James M. |date=2015-01-01 |title=On the Validity of the Regression Discontinuity Design for Estimating Electoral Effects: New Evidence from Over 40,000 Close Races |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Jens_Hainmueller/publication/280078057_On_the_Validity_of_the_Regression_Discontinuity_Design_for_Estimating_Electoral_Effects_New_Evidence_from_Over_40000_Close_Races/links/59c1a14a458515af305c8469/On-the-Validity-of-the-Regression-Discontinuity-Design-for-Estimating-Electoral-Effects-New-Evidence-from-Over-40-000-Close-Races.pdf |journal=American Journal of Political Science |volume=59 |issue=1 |pages=259–274 |doi=10.1111/ajps.12127 |issn=1540-5907}}{{Cite journal |last=Grimmer |first=Justin, Eitan Hirsh, Brian Feinstein, and Daniel Carpenter |year=2012 |title=Are Close Elections Random? Working Paper |publisher=Stanford|url=http://web.stanford.edu/~jgrimmer/CEF.pdf}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Election Contests, by Winning Margin |- ! scope="col" |Geographic Area ! scope="col" |Dates ! scope="col" |Includes Towns? ! scope="col" |Number of Election Contests ! scope="col" |Number of Ties ! scope="col" |Number Won by 1 Vote ! scope="col" |Percent of Elections where Winning Margin Was up to 0.1% ! scope="col" |Up to 0.2% ! scope="col" |Up to 0.5% ! scope="col" |Up to 1% ! scope="col" |Up to 2% ! scope="col" |Up to 5% ! scope="col" |Up to 90% ! scope="col" |Sources |- |Colorado||2017||yes||511||7||3||1.8%||2.2%||3.9%||5.3%||7.2%||16.4%||99.0%||[http://results.enr.clarityelections.com/CO/71802/Web02-state/#/ CO SoS] |- |Massachusetts||2014-17||most||456||0||0||0.2%||0.2%||1.5%||2.4%||4.8%||10.7%||98.7%||[http://electionstats.state.ma.us/ MA SoS] |- |West Virginia||2014-17||few||879||0||2||0.6%||1.0%||3.0%||4.4%||8.8%||21.3%||100.0%||[http://services.sos.wv.gov/apps/elections/results/Default.aspx WV SoS] |- |} ==See also== *[[Election audits]] *[[Elections]] *[[Electoral integrity]] *[[List of controversial elections]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Narrow Elections}} [[Category:Lists of elections]]

page.title: List of wedding guests of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer

revision.text:
The '''guest list at the [[wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer]]''' on 29 July 1981 included many members of [[royal families]] from across the world, republican heads of state, and members of the bride's and groom's families. As [[Charles, Prince of Wales|Prince Charles]] was heir to the British throne, the event was automatically deemed a "state occasion", formally requiring the invitation of many foreign heads of state; in addition, the marriage of the prince, who remained a bachelor until the age of 32, to the 20-year-old [[Diana, Princess of Wales|Lady Diana]] drew much attention from across the world. The guest list for the wedding, which took place at [[St Paul's Cathedral]] in [[London]], included 3,500 people.<ref name="bbcWeddingDay">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/july/29/newsid_2494000/2494949.stm|title=1981: Charles and Diana marry|date= 29 July 1982|accessdate=13 October 2008|work=BBC News}}</ref>
==Relatives of the groom==
===[[House of Windsor]]=== *[[Elizabeth II|The Queen]] and [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|The Duke of Edinburgh]], ''the groom's parents'' **[[Anne, Princess Royal|The Princess Anne, Mrs Phillips]] and Captain [[Mark Phillips]], ''the groom's sister and brother-in-law'' **[[Prince Andrew, Duke of York|The Prince Andrew]], ''the groom's brother'' **[[Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex|The Prince Edward]], ''the groom's brother'' *[[Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother]], ''the groom's maternal grandmother'' **[[The Princess Margaret, Countess of Snowdon]], ''the groom's aunt'' ***[[David Armstrong-Jones, 2nd Earl of Snowdon|Viscount Linley]], ''the groom's first cousin'' ***[[Lady Sarah Chatto|The Lady Sarah Armstrong-Jones]], ''the groom's first cousin'' *[[Princess Alice, Duchess of Gloucester]], ''the groom's great-aunt by marriage'' **[[Prince Richard, Duke of Gloucester|The Duke]] and [[Birgitte, Duchess of Gloucester|Duchess of Gloucester]], ''the groom's first cousin, once removed and his wife'' ***[[Alexander Windsor, Earl of Ulster|Earl of Ulster]], ''the groom's second cousin'' *[[Prince Edward, Duke of Kent|The Duke]] and [[Katharine, Duchess of Kent|Duchess of Kent]], ''the groom's first cousin, once removed and his wife'' **[[George Windsor, Earl of St Andrews|Earl of St Andrews]], ''the groom's second cousin'' **[[Lady Helen Taylor|The Lady Helen Windsor]], ''the groom's second cousin'' **[[Lord Nicholas Windsor|The Lord Nicholas Windsor]], ''the groom's second cousin'' (Page) *[[Princess Alexandra, The Honourable Lady Ogilvy|Princess Alexandra, The Honourable Mrs Ogilvy]] and The Honourable [[Angus Ogilvy]], ''the groom's first cousin, once removed and her husband'' **[[James Ogilvy|Mr James Ogilvy]], ''the groom's second cousin'' **Miss Marina Ogilvy, ''the groom's second cousin'' *[[Prince Michael of Kent|Prince]] and [[Princess Michael of Kent]], ''the groom's first cousin, once removed and his wife''
===[[Marquess of Cambridge|Teck-Cambridge family]]=== *[[Lady May Abel Smith|The Lady May]] and [[Henry Abel Smith|Colonel Sir Henry Abel Smith]], ''the groom's first cousin, twice removed and her husband'' *[[Lady Mary Whitley|The Lady Mary]] and Mr Peter Whitley, ''the groom's second cousin, once removed and her husband''
===[[Mountbatten family]]=== *[[Patricia Knatchbull, 2nd Countess Mountbatten of Burma|The Countess Mountbatten of Burma]] and [[John Knatchbull, 7th Baron Brabourne|The Lord Brabourne]], ''the groom's first cousin, once removed and her husband'' **[[Norton Knatchbull, 3rd Earl Mountbatten of Burma|Lord]] and [[Penelope Knatchbull, Countess Mountbatten of Burma|Lady Romsey]], ''the groom's second cousin and his wife'' **The Honourable Michael-John Knatchbull, ''the groom's second cousin'' **The Lady Joanna Knatchbull, ''the groom's second cousin'' **[[Lady Amanda Ellingworth|The Lady Amanda Knatchbull]], ''the groom's second cousin'' **The Honourable Philip Knatchbull, ''the groom's second cousin'' **The Honourable Timothy Knatchbull, ''the groom's second cousin'' *[[Lady Pamela Hicks|The Lady Pamela]] and [[David Nightingale Hicks|Mr David Hicks]], ''the groom's cousin, once removed and her husband'' **[[Edwina Brudenell|Miss Edwina Hicks]], ''the groom's second cousin'' **[[Ashley Hicks|Mr Ashley Hicks]], ''the groom's second cousin'' **[[India Hicks| Miss India Hicks]], ''the groom's second cousin'' (bridesmaid)
===[[Earl of Strathmore and Kinghorne|Bowes-Lyon family]]=== *[[Michael Bowes-Lyon, 17th Earl of Strathmore and Kinghorne|The Earl]] and Countess of Strathmore and Kinghorne, ''the groom's first cousin, once removed and his wife'' *[[Margaret Rhodes|The Honourable Mrs]] and [[Denys Rhodes|Mr Denys Rhodes]], ''the groom's first cousin, once removed and her husband''
==Relatives of the bride==
