{{CPW}} {{Diana, Princess of Wales}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:List of wedding guests of Charles, Prince of Wales, and Lady Diana Spencer}} [[Category:1981 in England]] [[Category:Charles, Prince of Wales]] [[Category:Diana, Princess of Wales]] [[Category:Marriage, unions and partnerships in England]] [[Category:Royal weddings]]

The '''Michelin Cup''' refers to a number of competitions sponsored by the French tyre manufacturer [[Michelin]] for long distance flight made in [[aeroplane]]s. [[File:Coupemichelin.jpg|thumb|]] The first Michelin prize was announced in March 1908. The principal prize, to be awarded annually for an initial period of eight years, was a prize for long distance flight, and consisted of a bronze statue as a trophy (valued at 10,000 FF-[[French francs]]) and a money prize of 20,000 FF. The flying club of the winner also received a replica of the trophy if they did not already own one. Administration and determination of the exact conditions for each year were delegated to the [[Aéro-Club de France]] (AeCF). Attempts to win the prize could be made anywhere in the world where there was a flying club associated with the AeCF.
At the same time, '''Prix d'Aviation Michelin''' was a special prize of 100,000 francs offered for a flight by an aircraft carrying a passenger, taking off from either the department of [[Seine]] or [[Seine-et-Oise]], flying over the [[Arc de Triomphe]] and the cathedral of [[Clermont-Ferrand]], and landing on the summit of the {{convert|1456|m|ft|abbr=on}} [[Puy de Dôme]] inside six hours starting from the time at the Arc de Triomphe.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url= http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6550620m/f125.image.r=Michelin.langEN|page=115|language=French|date=March 1908|title=La Coupe d'Aviation et les Prix d'Aviation Michelin}}</ref> This was won by [[Eugène Renaux]] on 7 March 1911, flying a [[Farman MF.7|Maurice Farman biplane]].<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1911/1911%20-%200205.html|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|date=11 March 1911|title =Renaux wins the Michelin Puy de Dome Prize|page=207}}</ref>
In 1909, a second award, the '''British Empire Michelin Cup''', was announced, for flights made by aviators who were citizens of the British Empire, flying aircraft of all-British manufacture. The original award therefore became known as the '''International Michelin Cup'''.
When the prizes were first instituted, 25 [[French franc]]s were worth one [[pound Sterling]].<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1909/1909%20-%200181.html|title=Prize Treatise on Aerial Navigation|date=27 March 1909|page=183}}</ref>
==International Michelin Cup==
===1908=== Won by [[Wilbur Wright]] with a flight made on 31 December 1908 at [[Le Mans]] officially reckoned as {{convert|124.7|km|mi|abbr=on}}. The course over which the flight was made was an isosceles triangle with two sides of 1 km and a third of 200 m, totalling 2.2 km. The flight had to be made before sunset and only complete circuits counted. Wright took off at 2 pm and completed 56 circuits before sunset. He then landed, flying a further 1.5 km to set a new world distance record of 124.7 km.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1909/1909%20-%200022.html|date=9 Jan 1924|title=Wright's Final Effort for the 1908 Michelin Prize. |page=24}}</ref>
===1909=== For the greatest distance exceeding 123.2 km. in a closed circuit made before the end of the year: 20,000 francs, and a bronze replica of the Michelin trophy.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|title=Michelin Cup Rules for 1909 |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1909/1909%20-%200050.html|date=23 January 1909|page= 52}}</ref>
Won by [[Henry Farman]] with a flight of {{convert|234.212|km|mi|abbr=on}} lasting 4h 6m 25s made on 3 November 1909 at [[Châlons-en-Champagne|Chalons]].<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k65523525/f13.image.|title=Pour la Coupe Michelin|date=1 January 1911|page=7|language=French}}</ref>
===1910=== Won by [[Maurice Tabuteau]] flying a [[Farman MF.7|Maurice Farman biplane]] with a flight of {{convert|584.745|km|mi|abbr=on}}, taking 7hr 48m 36.6s at Buc on 30 December 1910.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url= http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k65523525/f32.image.n|title=La Coupe Michelin|date=1 January 1911|page=26|language=French}}</ref>
===1911=== In 1911, the closing date for the competition was brought forward to 31 October.
Won by E. Helen flying a [[Nieuport II]] monoplane on 8 September 1911, when he covered {{convert|1,252.8|km|mi|abbr=on}} in 14 hr 7 min.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1911/1911%20-%200964.html|title=Helen wins Michelin Cup|date=4 November 1911|page=966}}</ref>
===1912=== For the 1912 competition, the rules were considerably elaborated. The flight had to be made over a course made up of three different circuits, each starting from the same point. The first and third, each of about {{convert|500|km|mi|abbr=on}}, had to have three or four compulsory landing-places, and the second, of {{convert|255|km|mi|abbr=on}}, one or two landing places. Refuelling was only allowed at the starting point of each circuit. The circuits had to be covered in order, and if a competitor landed somewhere other than a nominated airfield, they had to start that circuit again. For every 75 kg of useful load carried apart from the pilot and necessary fuel, a bonus of 25% was allowed on the time, up to a maximum of 100 per cent. The extra load could be made up of passengers or ballast. Competing aircraft had to carry a sealed [[barograph]], and an average speed of at least {{convert|40|kph|mph|abbr=on}} had to be maintained.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1912/1912%20-%200179.html|title=1912 International Michelin Competition|date=24 February 1912|page=179 }}</ref>
The 1912 prize was not won by any competitor, and the prize money was added to the prize for the following year.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url= http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6552332d/f386.image.r=coupe%20michelin378|date=15 August 1913|title=Pour La Coupe Michelin}}</ref>
===1913=== The 1913 competition was very different. It was awarded for the greatest distance flown on a series of consecutive days, flying over a {{convert|100|km|mi|abbr=on}} course, with a compulsory landing after each circuit.
The Cup was won by Emmanuel Helen flying a Nieuport monoplane, with a total distance of {{convert|16096.6|km|mi|abbr=on}} flown between 22 October and 29 November 1913.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|title=Helen's Record for the Michelin Cup|url= http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1913/1913%20-%201305.html|page=1331|date=6 December 1913}}</ref>
===1914=== The nature of the competition was changed again for the 1914 competition, the prize being awarded for the fastest time over a circuit of about {{convert|3000|km|mi|abbr=on}}. Won by [[Eugène Gilbert]] flying a Morane-Saulnier monoplane. Starting from [[Villacoublay]] at 03:04 on 8 June 1914, he flew via [[Péronne, Somme|Peronne]], [[Rheims]], [[Saint-Dizier]], [[Gray, Haute-Saône|Gray]], [[Joigny]], [[Beaune]], [[Vienne]] and [[Nimes]], landing at [[Mirande]] before reaching [[Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Pau]], owing to running out of fuel. On the next day he flew via Pau, [[Saint-André-de-Cubzac|St. André de Cubzac]], [[Romorantin]], [[Angers]], [[Evreux]] and [[Calais]] back to Villacoublay, landing at 18:37 p.m, having covered a distance of {{convert|2970|km|mi|abbr=on}} in 39h 35m.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1914/1914%20-%200636.html|title=Gilbert Flies Round France in Two Days|date=June 12, 1914|page=636}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6585089x/f29.image|title=Performances de la Quinzaine|page=301|date= 1 July 1914}}</ref>
===1921=== After the [[First World War]], the competition was resumed in 1921. The competition was for the fastest time over a (3,000 km {1,860 mi) circuit: the French circuit was [[Versailles (city)|Versailles]]—[[Amiens]]—[[Mourmelon-le-Grand]]—[[Saint-Dizier]]—[[Dijon]]—[[Joigny]]—[[Beaune]]—[[Lyon]]—[[Nîmes]]—[[Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Pau]]—[[Bordeaux]]–[[Romorantin]],—[[Angers]]—[[Évreux]]—[[Calais]]—Versailles, and the aircraft had to land at each of these airfields.
The result was the cause of considerable controversy. The best French time was achieved by [[Alphonse Poiré]] flying a [[Caudron C.60]], who completed the circuit in 37h 23m.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1921/1921%20-%200608.html|title= The International Michelin Cup|date=8 September 1921|page= 608}}</ref> A faster time of 35h 45m over an Italian circuit was achieved by Capt Raffaele Martinetti-Bianchi<ref>L'Aéreophile 1-15 octobre 1921</ref>,<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url= http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1921/1921%20-%200859.html|date= 29 December 1921|page=859|title=The Michelin Cup}}</ref> but he had not landed at the same aerodrome as he had departed from, since this had become waterlogged and he was not allowed to land there. The dispute between the Italian authorities, who had ratified his performance, and the Aéro-Club de France was taken to a specially appointed [[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale]] committee, which found in Martinetti's favour, but the AeCF disputed their judgement: eventually the prize was held to have been won by neither man, although in recognition of his performance the AeCF awarded the Gold Medal of the AeCF and a sum of money equal to the Michelin Prize to Poiré.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6555017m/f162.image.r=Martinetti|title=Comité de Direction|date=1 May 1923|page=156}}</ref>
===1922-3=== A five-year extension, with annual prizes of 20,000 francs, was announced in 1922. The time period of the annual competition was altered to run from the beginning of July in one year to the end of the following June.
Won by Capt Girier flying a [[Breguet 14]], taking 20hr 41m 57sec, covering the course [[Lyons]]—[[Nimes]]—[[Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Pau]]—[[Bordeaux]]—[[Angers]]—[[Saint-Inglevert|St. Inglevert]]—[[Mourmelon-le-Grand|Mourmelon]]—[[Metz]]—[[Strasbourg]]—[[Dijon]]—[[Avord]]—Lyons at an average speed (including time on the ground) of {{convert|136.2|kph|mph|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6555017m/f213.image|page=201|date=1 July 1923|title= La Coupe Michelin}}</ref>
===1923-4=== The 1924 French circuit was [[Versailles (city)|Versailles]]—[[Saint-Inglevert]]—[[Valenciennes]]—[[Mourmelon-le-Grand|Mourmelon]]—[[Metz]]—[[Strasbourg]]—[[Dijon]]—[[Clermont-Ferrand]]—[[Lyon]]—[[Nimes]]—[[Toulouse]]—[[Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Pau]]—[[Bordeaux]]—[[Angers]]—Versailles
Won by Lieut. [[Ludovic Arrachart]] flying a [[Breguet 19]], completing the {{convert|2935|km|mi|abbr=on}} in 19h 22m 26s.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]] 1924 ''Salon Aéronautique'' issue |url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6554816n/f429.image|title=Les Moteurs d'Aviation Renault|page=31 }}</ref>
===1924-5=== Won by [[Pelletier d'Oisy]] flying a [[Blériot-SPAD S.61]], completing the course in 15h 8m.<ref name=Raids>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6553816b/f203.image|title=Raids, Records et Performances|page=197|date=1 July 1925}}</ref>
===1925-6=== At the request of the military aviation authorities, the 1925-6 competition was limited to competitors flying the principal French bombing aircraft, the [[Breguet 19]].<ref name=Raids/> The best time was achieved by Capt. Coslin, with Lieut Gérard as observer, with a time of 18h 0m 24s, a speed of {{convert|163.6|kph|mph|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url= http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k65547488/f205.image|title=La Coupe Michelin|date=1 July 1926| page=199}}</ref>
However, since this time did not better the previous best, the cup did not change hands.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6553815x/f242.image|title=Les Coupe Michelin | date=1 August 1927 |page=236 }}</ref>
===1926-7=== There were two competitions in 1926-7, one restricted to the Breguet 19. The course for both competitions was Paris ([[Paris–Le Bourget Airport|Le Bourget]])—[[Nancy, France|Nancy]]—[[Metz]]—[[Strasbourg]]—[[Dijon]]—[[Bourges]]—[[Clermont-Ferrand]]—[[Lyons]]—[[Istres]]—[[Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Pau]]—[[Cazaux Air Base|Casaux]]—[[Châteauroux]]—[[Tours]]—[[Romorantin-Lanthenay|Romorantin]]—[[Chartres]]—Paris, a distance of {{convert|2727.5|km|mi|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k65547488/f165.image|date= 1 May 1926|title=Nouvell Coupe Michelin|page=159|language=French}}</ref>
The main competition was won by Capitain Challes flying a [[Blériot-SPAD S.61]] in 12h 14m 37s.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1927/1927%20-%200470.html|title=The Michelin Cup|date= 30 June 1927|page= 428}}</ref>
The military competition was won by Capt Delaître and Sgt Cailloge, who covered the course in 14h 51m 55s, a speed of {{convert|187.95|kph|mph|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k65538437/f30.image|title=Réception des Lauréats des Militaries|date=1 February 1928|page= 62}}</ref>
===1927-8=== Again, the competition was restricted to the Breguet 19, with the added condition that an altitude of {{convert|4000|m|ft|abbr=on}} be reached at least once.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6553846g/f27.image.r=coupe%20michelin|title=Les Militaries 1928|date=1 May 1928|page=155}}</ref>
Won by Capt. Delaître.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]] |url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6553851s/f29.image|title=Commission Sportive|date= 1 October 1928|page=317}}</ref>
===1928-9=== In 1928, the prize was offered for a further four years. The winning flight had to be made in France, although the competition was open to all nationalities, and the competition was restricted to single-seater aircraft with an engine of 230 hp or less. A minimum average speed of {{convert|185|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} had to be maintained over the circuit, including time spent on the ground at the fifteen cities making up the circuit.<ref name=F32_623>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url= http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1932/1932%20-%200671.html|date= 8 July 1932|page=623 |title=The Michelin Cup}}</ref> Won by [[Michel Détroyat]], flying a [[Morane-Saulnier MS.230]].<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1930/untitled0%20-%200683.html|date= 20 June 1920|page= 651|title=Vincennes}}</ref>
===1929-30=== Won by [[Michel Détroyat]], flying a [[Morane-Saulnier MS.130]], completing the {{convert|2788|km|mi|abbr=on}} course [[Paris–Le Bourget Airport|Paris (Le Bourget)]]—[[Reims]]—[[Nancy, France|Nancy]]— [[Strasbourg]]—[[Dijon]]—[[Clermont-Ferrand]]—[[Lyons]]—[[Montpellier]]— [[Perpignan]]—[[Toulouse]]—[[Pau, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Pau]]—[[Bordeaux]]—[[Tours]]—Le Bourget at an average speed of {{convert|190.2|kph|mph|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6554360b/f216.image.|title=L'Aviation Français|date=1 July 1930|page=210 }}</ref>
===1930-31=== Won by [[Marcel Haegelen]] flying the Lorraine-Hanriot LH.41, with a time of 11h 37m 21s, an average speed of {{convert|226.45|kph|mph|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6553565s/f12.image|title=Coupe Michelin|date=15 July 1931|page=204}}</ref>
===1931-2=== Won by [[Marcel Haegelen]] flying the Lorraine-Hanriot LH 41, completing the {{convert|2631|km|mi|abbr=on}} course at an average speed of {{convert|254|kph|mph|abbr=on}} on 23 June 1932.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k65536654/f30.image|title=Commission Sportive| date=August 1932 |page=254 }}</ref>
===1932–3=== Won by Michel Détroyat flying a [[Morane-Saulnier MS.230#Variants|Moraine Saulnier MS.234]], completing the {{convert| 2902|km|mi|abbr=on}} course at an average speed of {{convert|222.537|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k65535577/f8.image|title=La Coupe Michelin|date=November 1933|page=328 }}</ref>
===1934===
===1935=== Won by Maurice Arnoux flying a [[Caudron C.430|Caudron C.430/1]], completing the {{convert|2902|km|mi|abbr=on}} course in 10h 7m, a speed of {{convert|286.85|kph|mph|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k65547614/f41.image|title= La Coupe Michelin|date= November 1935|page=341}}</ref>
==British Michelin cup== In 1909, Michelin instituted a United Kingdom award, offering an annual award for five years of a trophy and £500. The competition was limited to British subjects flying aircraft of British construction. Administration of the competition was entrusted to the [[Royal Aero Club|Aero Club of Great Britain]]. <ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1909/1909%20-%200185.html|date= 27 March 1909 |page=187|title=A British Michelin Cup }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]| url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1910/1910%20-%200758.html|date=17 September 1910|page=756|title=The British Empire Michelin Cup }}</ref>
===1909–10=== For the first year, the flight was to be around a closed circuit made up of two or more markers, and a minimum distance of {{convert|5|mi|km}} was specified. The closing date for the first competition was 31 March 1910.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1910/1910%20-%200189.html|page= 185|date=8 March 1910|title=The British Empire Michelin Cup}}</ref>
Won by [[John Moore-Brabazon, 1st Baron Brabazon of Tara|J. T. C. Moore-Brabazon]] with a flight of {{convert|18.75|mi|km|abbr=on}} at [[RNAS Eastchurch|Eastchurch]] on 1 March 1910, flying the [[Short Biplane No. 2]].<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|title=British Michelin Trophy Winner|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1910/1910%20-%200279.html|page=277|date =9 April 1910}}</ref>
===1910=== The rules for the 1910 competition, for which the closing date was 31 December 1910, were as before except that the minimum qualifying distance was raised to {{convert|38|mi|km|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1910/1910%20-%200758.html|date= 17 September 1910|title=The British Empire Michelin Cup}}</ref>
Won by [[Samuel Franklin Cody|Samuel Cody]] flying the [[Cody Michelin Cup Biplane]] at Laffan's Plain, Farnborough with a flight of {{convert|185.46|mi|km|abbr=on}} taking 4h 47m.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1911/1911%20-%200007.html|date=7 January 1911|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|title=The British Michelin Cup| page=7 }}</ref>
===1911=== Announcement of a second prize, to be competed for during the following three years, with a trophy and a cash prize of £400 for 1911, £600 for 1912 and £800 for 1913, for the fastest time over a cross-country circuit.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1911/1911%20-%200292.html|date= April 1911|title=British Empire Michelin Cup No.2|page=294}}</ref>
On 29 October 1911, the Michelin Cup No. 1 was again won by Samuel Cody, flying his [[Cody Circuit of Britain biplane|Circuit of Britain biplane]] {{convert|261.5|mi|km}} in 5 hr 15 min at Laffan's Plain, also setting a new British duration record.<ref name= FL1911/>
The No. 2 cup was also won by Cody, with a flight made on 11 September 1911 of a circuit starting at Laffan's Plain, [[Farnborough, Hampshire|Farnborough]]—[[Andover, Hampshire|Andover]]—[[Hendon Aerodrome|Hendon]]—[[Brooklands]]—Farnborough, taking 3 hr 6 min 30 sec to complete the {{convert|125|mi|km}} course.<ref name= FL1911>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |url= http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1911/1911%20-%200980.html|title=Official Notices |date=11 November 1911 |page=982 }}</ref>
===1912=== The rules were redefined for the 1912 competition: the No. 1 cup and cash prize of £5,000 was purely for endurance, all flying to be done between sunrise and sunset. The No. 2 cup and prize of £600 was for distance covered over a cross-country course of about {{convert|186|mi|km|abbr=on}} of the competitor's choosing.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url= http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1912/1912%20-%200468.html|date=25 May 1912 |title=Notices to Members |page= }}</ref>
The No. 1 cup was won by [[Harry Hawker]] flying the [[Sopwith-Wright biplane]], with a flight lasting 8 hours 23 minutes made on 24 October 1912 at [[Brooklands]].<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1912/1912%20-%201005.html|date=2 November 1912|title=British Duration Records|page=1005}}</ref>
The No. 2 cup was won by Samuel Cody flying the [[Cody V]], with a flight of 186 miles in 3hr 26m.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]] |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1912/1912%20-%200946.html|title= Col. Cody Again Wins Michelin Cup No. 2. |date=19 October 1912 |page=946 }}</ref>
===1913=== Michelin Cup No. 1 for the longest distance flight round the course Brooklands–Hendon–[[Farnborough, Hampshire|Farnborough]], with a minimum distance of 300 miles. Competitors had to make periodical stops of not less than five minutes, with engine stopped, on completing an entire circuit of the course plus one section: e.g., starting from Brooklands the competitor would pass Hendon, Farnborough, Brooklands, and alight at Hendon.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|title=The British Empire Michelin Cup No. 1|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1913/1913%20-%200404.html|date= 12 April 1913|page= 412}}</ref> The prize had not been won by the closing date of 31 October 1913, so the closing date was extended to 14 November 1913.
The No. 1 Cup was won by [[Reginald H. Carr]] flying the [[Grahame-White Type X|Grahame White "Charabanc"]], with a flight of over {{convert|300|mi|km|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|title= Reginald H. Carr|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1913/1913%20-%201238.html|date= 22 November 1913|page= 1261}}</ref>
The No. 2 cup, for the fastest time round a circuit of the competitor's choice of about 450 km, was not awarded. Although the prize was carried over to the next year, competition was terminated by the outbreak of [[World War I]].<ref>{{cite journal|journal=[[Flight International|Flight]]|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1914/1914%20-%200342.html|title=Notices to members|date=28 March 1914|page=342}}</ref>

{{Infobox spaceflight | name = NASA-ISRO synthetic aperture radar (NISAR) | image = [[File:NISAR artist concept.jpg|280px]] | image_caption = Artist concept of the NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar (NISAR) satellite in orbit. | insignia = NISAR_Mission_Logo.png | mission_type = [[Synthetic-aperture_radar|Radar]] imaging | operator = [[NASA]]{{,}}[[Indian Space Research Organisation|ISRO]] | website = {{url|http://nisar.jpl.nasa.gov/}}
{{url|http://www.sac.gov.in/nisar/}} | COSPAR_ID = | SATCAT = | mission_duration = 3.25 years{{cite web|title=Optimization of Debris Shields on the NISAR Mission’s L-Band Radar Instrument|url=https://conference.sdo.esoc.esa.int/proceedings/sdc7/paper/46/SDC7-paper46.pdf|website=conference.sdo.esoc.esa.int|publisher=ESA Space Debris Office|accessdate=21 July 2017}} | Details = | spacecraft_bus = [[I-3K]]{{cite web |title=Overview of NISAR Mission and Airborne L & S SAR |url=https://vedas.sac.gov.in/vedas/downloads/ertd/SAR/L_1.pdf |website=SAC.gov.in |publisher=Space Applications Centre, ISRO |accessdate=23 November 2018}} | manufacturer = | dry_mass = | launch_mass = {{convert|2,800|kg|lb|abbr=on}}{{cite web |last1=Neeck |first1=Steven |title=The NASA Earth Science Program and Small Satellites |url=https://www.dlr.de/iaa.symp/Portaldata/49/Resources/dokumente/archiv10/pdf/IAA-10-0101_kl.pdf |website=DLR.de |accessdate=23 November 2018}} | power = | launch_date = 2020-21 (planned){{cite news|last1=Bagla|first1=Pallava|title=The First Ever Satellite Being Jointly Built By NASA And ISRO Will Do This|url=http://www.ndtv.com/india-news/the-first-ever-satellite-being-jointly-built-by-nasa-and-isro-will-do-this-1695926|accessdate=19 May 2017}} | launch_rocket = [[Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle]]
(4 meter fairing) | launch_site = [[Satish Dhawan Space Center]] | launch_contractor = | disposal_type = | deactivated = | last_contact = | decay_date = | orbit_epoch = | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]]{{cite web|url=http://www.wmo-sat.info/oscar/satelliteprogrammes/view/249 |title=Satellite Programme: NASA ISRO-Synthetic Aperture Radar |work=[[World Meteorological Organization]] |accessdate=2 July 2014}} | orbit_regime = [[Low Earth orbit|Low Earth]]
{{small|[[Sun-synchronous orbit|Sun-synchronous]]}}{{cite web |url=http://www.sac.gov.in/nisar/NisarMission.html |title=NISAR Mission}} | orbit_periapsis = | orbit_apoapsis = | orbit_inclination = 98.5° | orbit_period = | orbit_altitude = {{convert|747|km|mi|sp=us}} | apsis = gee }} The '''NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar''' ('''NISAR''') mission is a joint project between [[NASA]] and [[ISRO]] to co-develop and launch a dual frequency [[synthetic aperture radar]] satellite. The satellite will be the first [[radar imaging]] satellite to use dual frequency and it is planned to be used for [[remote sensing]] to observe and understand natural processes on Earth. ==Description== The NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar, or NISAR satellite, will provide an unprecedented detailed view of Earth by using advanced radar imaging. It is designed to observe and take measurements of some of the planet's most complex processes, including [[Disturbance (ecology)|ecosystem disturbances]], [[Ice-sheet dynamics|ice-sheet collapse]], and natural hazards such as [[earthquake]]s, [[tsunami]]s, [[volcano]]es and [[landslide]]s.{{cite web |url=http://nisar.jpl.nasa.gov/ |title=NASA-ISRO SAR Mission (NISAR) |work=[[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate=2 July 2014}} Under the terms of the agreement, NASA will provide the mission's L-band [[synthetic aperture radar]] (SAR), a high-rate communication subsystem for science data, GPS receivers, a solid state recorder, and a payload data subsystem. ISRO will provide the [[satellite bus]], an [[S-band]] synthetic aperture radar, the launch vehicle and associated launch services.{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/press/2014/september/us-india-to-collaborate-on-mars-exploration-earth-observing-mission/ |title=U.S., India to Collaborate on Mars Exploration, Earth-Observing Mission |work=[[NASA]] |date=Sep 30, 2014 |accessdate=8 October 2014}} Data collected from NISAR will reveal information about the evolution and state of Earth's crust, help scientists better understand our planet's processes and [[Climate change|changing climate]], and aid future resource and hazard management. The mission is a partnership between [[NASA]] and [[ISRO]].{{cite web |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/missions/nasa-isro-synthetic-aperture-radar-nisar/ |title=NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperature Radar |work=[[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate=24 January 2017}} The satellite design will make use of a large deployable mesh antenna and will operate on dual [[L band]] and [[S band]]. The 12-meter aperture mesh reflector will be supplied by [[Astro Aerospace]], a [[Northrop Grumman]] company.http://globenewswire.com/news-release/2015/10/30/781817/10154634/en/NASA-Jet-Propulsion-Laboratory-Selects-Northrop-Grumman-s-Astro-Aerospace-for-NISAR-Reflector.html The satellite will be launched from India aboard an [[Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle]].{{cite web |url=http://isp.justthe80.com/space-applications/cartography-mapping-surveillance-satellites/nasa-isro-radar-satellite |title=NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar Radar Satellite (NI-SAR) |accessdate=2 July 2014}}{{Cite web|url=http://164.100.158.235/question/annex/243/Au2223.pdf|title=Rajyasabha Q.No. 2223, Session:243 "JOINT PROJECT BETWEEN NASA AND ISRO"|last=|first=|date=3 August 2017|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite news|url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=169570|title=Joint Project between NASA and ISRO|last=|first=|date=3 August 2017|work=Press Information Bureau, Government of India|access-date=3 August 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} The satellite will be 3-axis stabilised and is planned to be launched into a [[Sun-synchronous orbit|Sun-synchronous]] dawn to dusk orbit with a mission life of 3 years. The project has passed the first stage of the design validation phase and has been reviewed and approved by NASA. Shared cost of project for ISRO is about {{INRConvert|788|c}} and for NASA it is about US$808 million. ==Payload== * [[L-band]] (24-centimeter wavelength) [[Polarimetry|polarimetric]] [[Synthetic Aperture Radar|SAR]], to be produced by NASA. * [[S-band]] (12-centimeter wavelength) [[Polarimetry|polarimetric]] [[Synthetic Aperture Radar|SAR]], to be produced by ISRO.{{cite web |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/Home/Science/Isros-instrument-design-passes-Nasa-review/articleshow/39369930.cms |title=Isro's instrument design passes Nasa review |work=[[The Times of India]] |accessdate=2 July 2014}} ==See also== * [[Indian Remote Sensing]] * [[List of Indian satellites]] * [[Seasat]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Indian space programme}} {{Indian spacecraft}} {{NASA space program}} {{Space-based meteorological observation}} {{Future spaceflights}} [[Category:ISRO satellites]] [[Category:Remote sensing]] [[Category:India–United States relations]] [[Category:NASA satellites]] [[Category:2020 in spaceflight]] [[Category:Space synthetic aperture radar]]

:''Not to be confused with [[Noisefest]] {{Infobox music festival | name =Noise Fest | image = | caption = | location =[[New York City]] art space [[White Columns]] | years_active = | founders =[[Thurston Moore]] | dates =June 1981 | genre = [[Experimental music]], [[no wave]] [[noise music]]| attendance = | capacity = | website = }} '''Noise Fest''' was an influential festival of [[no wave]] [[noise music]] performances curated by [[Thurston Moore]] of [[Sonic Youth]] at the [[New York City]] art space [[White Columns]] in June 1981. [[Sonic Youth]] made their first live appearances at this show.<ref>[[Simon Reynolds]], ''Rip It Up and Start Again: Post-punk 1978-1984'' (2006) Penguin</ref> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Noise Fest.jpg|thumb|250px|ZG records Noise Fest cover {{deletable image-caption}}]] -->
In mid 1981 [[Kim Gordon]] and Josh Baer convinced Thurston Moore to organize this nine-day noise festival to accommodate underemployed experimental performers in the downtown scene. The festival was held in the [[White Columns]] gallery, which had a capacity of 60 people. Each night three to five acts performed, including [[Glenn Branca]], [[Rhys Chatham]], Jeffrey Lohn, Built on Guilt, [[Rudolph Grey]], the Avant Squares, Off Beach, Mofungo, Red Decade, NNB, [[Robin Crutchfield]]'s Dark Day, Ad Hoc Rock, Smoking Section, Chinese Puzzle, Avoidance Behaviour, and [[Sonic Youth]].<ref>Marc Masters, (2007) [[No Wave]] London, Black Dog Publishing, pp. 170-171</ref>
==Recording history== In 1978 a similar series of [[punk rock]] influenced loud [[noise music]] mixed with [[performance art]] was held at New York’s Artists’ Space that led to the [[Brian Eno]]-produced recording ''[[No New York]]''. This recording was seen by many as the first attempt to define the [[no wave]] sound, as it documented [[James Chance and the Contortions|The Contortions]], [[Teenage Jesus and the Jerks]], [[Mars (band)|Mars]] and [[DNA (No Wave band)|DNA]].
Music from the '''Noise Festival''' was first released as a cassette titled ''Noise Fest'' on ZG Music in 1981; the music label of the legendary ZG magazine organized by Rosetta Brookes. All material was recorded live at White Columns. This included the music of John Rehnberger, Off Beach, Ut, [[Lee Ranaldo]], Mofungo, [[Phil_Shoenfelt | Khmer Rouge]], The Problem, Smoking Section, [[Sonic Youth]], Jeff Lohn, Ima, Jules Baptiste Red Decade, EQ'D, Avant Squares, Don King, Primivites, Ad Hoc Rock, Y Pants, Barbotemagus (as it is spelled on the cover), Economical Animal, Chinese Puzzle, Glorious Strangers, Built On Guilt, Fakir, Lampshades. In 1982 the ''Noise Festival Tape'' was released by [[White Columns]].
==Influence== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Speedtrials.jpg|thumb|250px|Speed Trials program {{deletable image-caption}}]] --> Noise Fest inspired the '''Speed Trials''' [[noise rock]] series organized by [[Live Skull]] members in May 1983 at [[White Columns]]. Among an [[art installation]] created by [[David Wojnarowicz]] and [[Joseph Nechvatal]], various [[performance art]]ists such as Ilona Granet and Emily XYZ did their acts intermixing with the music of [[The Fall (band)|The Fall]], [[Beastie Boys]], [[Live Skull]], [[Sonic Youth]], [[Lydia Lunch]], [[Elliott Sharp]], [[Swans (band)|Swans]] and [[Arto Lindsay]].
''Speed Trials'' was eventually released as a live album recorded by Mark Roule and became one of the best-selling independent records of its time.<ref>[[Carlo McCormick]], ''The [[Downtown]] Book: The New York Art Scene, 1974–1984'', [[Princeton University]] Press, 2006</ref>
==Discography== *''Noise Festival Tape'' (1982) TSoWC [[White Columns]] *''Noise Fest'' (1981) cassette tape, ZG Music *''Speed Trials'' (1984) Homestead Records HMS-011
==References== *Marc Masters, (2007) "[[No Wave]]", Black Dog Publishing, London *Paul Hegarty, ''Noise/Music: A History'' (2007) Continuum International Publishing Group *[[RoseLee Goldberg]], ''Performance: Live Art Since 1960'' (1998) Harry N. Abrams, NY NY *[[Thurston Moore]], ''Mix Tape: The Art of Cassette Culture'' (2004) Universe

'''Operation Delego<ref name="Operation Delego">{{cite web |title=Operation Delego Court Documents |url=http://www.justice.gov/opa/delego-docs.html |date= |publisher=US Department of Justice |accessdate=5 August 2011}}</ref>''' is a major international law enforcement <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/44002915/ns/us_news-crime_and_courts/t/living-horror-dozens-charged-international-child-porn-ring/?fb_ref=.TjnKfstIF7I.like&fb_source=other_multiline#.Tjr_cCw_50h |title=Dozens charged in child porn ring bust |work=US news - Crime & courts |publisher=MSNBC |date=2011-05-08 |accessdate=2011-08-06}}</ref> investigation launched in 2009, which dismantled an international [[pedophilia|pedophile]] ring that operated an invitation-only Internet site named Dreamboard which featured incentives for images of the violent sexual abuse of young children under twelve, including infants. Only 72 charges were filed against the approximately 600 members of Dreamboard due to the extensive [[encryption]] involved. Members were required to upload new material at least every 50 days to maintain their access and remain in good standing.
Operation Delego is a spinoff investigation from leads developed through "Operation Nest Egg," the prosecution of another online group dedicated to sharing and disseminating child pornography. Operation Nest Egg was a spinoff investigation developed from leads related to another international investigation, "Operation Joint Hammer," which targeted transnational rings of child pornography trafficking.<ref name=wyss-sentence /> Dozens of law enforcement agencies were involved worldwide in Delego,<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite press release |url=https://www.dhs.gov/ynews/releases/20110803-napolitano-holder-announce-largest-prosecution-criminal-network.shtm |title=DHS: Secretary Napolitano and Attorney General Holder Announce Largest U.S. Prosecution of International Criminal Network Organized to Sexually Exploit Children |publisher=[[Department of Homeland Security]]-Dhs.gov |date=2011-08-03 |accessdate=2011-08-06}}</ref> including [[Eurojust]], and arrests were made on all five continents.<ref>{{cite web |author= |url=http://capitalregion.ynn.com/content/top_stories/552291/72-charged-in-federal-child-porn-bust/ |title=72 charged in federal child porn bust |work= Your News Now |publisher=Capitalregion.ynn.com |date=2011-08-04 |accessdate=2011-08-06}}</ref> Twenty of those charged, however, are only known by their Internet handles, and as such were individually charged as [[John Doe]]s and remain at large. However, some of the indictments were unsealed as of August 2011, and the names of some of those involved in Dreamboard are publicly available.
[[United States Department of Homeland Security]] Secretary [[Janet Napolitano]] stated at a news conference that "The board may have been the vehicle for the distribution of up to 123 terabytes of child pornography, which is roughly equivalent to 16,000 DVDs," making this the DHS's largest child porn bust in its history. Launched in 2009 by federal law enforcement, Operation Delego resulted in the arrest of 52 people in 14 countries including [[Canada]], [[Denmark]], [[Ecuador]], [[France]], [[Germany]], [[Hungary]], [[Kenya]], the [[Netherlands]], the [[Philippines]], [[Qatar]], [[Serbia]], [[Sweden]] and [[Switzerland]], according to [[United States Department of Justice]] Attorney General [[Eric Holder]]. Furthermore, according to federal agents, while Dreamboard's servers were located in [[Shreveport, Louisiana|Shreveport]], [[Louisiana]], the site's top administrators were in France and Canada.
Operation Delego is ongoing.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
== Arrests == Arrests have occurred in the following countries: Canada, Denmark, Ecuador, France, Germany, Hungary, Kenya, the Netherlands, the Philippines, Qatar, Serbia, Sweden, Switzerland, the US.<ref name=multi-sentence/>
==Convictions == * On May 10, 2011, Timothy Lee Gentry, 33, of Burlington, Ky., was sentenced to 25 years in prison.<ref name=multi-sentence/> * On May 31, 2011, Michael Biggs, 32, of Orlando, Fla., was sentenced to 20 years in prison.<ref name=multi-sentence/> * On June 22, 2011, Michael Childs, 49, of Huntsville, Ala., was sentenced to 30 years in prison.<ref name=multi-sentence/> * On July 14, 2011, Charles Christian, 49, of Tilton, Ill., was sentenced to more than 22 years in prison.<ref name=multi-sentence>{{cite web |url=https://www.ice.gov/news/releases/1108/110803washingtondc.htm |title=Indictments unsealed against individuals on 5 continents involved in child exploitation network |publisher=U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice.gov) |date=2011-08-03 |accessdate=2014-03-25}}</ref> * On July 17, 2012, Robert Cuff, 49, was sentenced to life in prison for producing and distributing child pornography.<ref name=ice-shreveport/> * Jonathan Mayer, 29, of Newport, Tenn., and Shane Micah Turner, 33, of Roy, Utah, were sentenced in connection with their participation in the Dreamboard bulletin board. Each received a sentence of 17 ½ years in prison followed by lifetime supervised release, as a result of both defendants pleading guilty to conspiring to advertise child pornography. The sentences were handed down by U.S. District Judge S. Maurice Hicks.<ref name=ice-shreveport>{{cite web |url=https://www.ice.gov/news/releases/1207/120718shreveport.htm |title=Child predator sentenced to life imprisonment in Louisiana |publisher=Ice.gov |date=2012-07-18 |accessdate=2014-03-25}}</ref> * On May 17, 2012 John Wyss, aka "Bones," 55, of [[Monroe, Wisconsin]], was found guilty, after a four-day jury trial, of one count of engaging in a child exploitation enterprise, one count of conspiracy to advertise child pornography and one count of conspiracy to distribute child pornography.<ref name=ice-wyss/> In September 2012 Wyss was sentenced to life in prison.<ref name=wyss-sentence>{{cite web |url=https://www.ice.gov/news/releases/1209/120906washingtondc.htm |title=Third 'Dreamboard' member sentenced to life in prison for participating in international criminal network organized to sexually exploit children |publisher=Ice.gov |date=2012-09-06 |accessdate=2014-03-25}}</ref>
A total of 72 individuals, including Wyss, have been charged as a result of Operation Delego. To date, 57 of the 72 charged defendants have been arrested in the United States and abroad.<ref name=doj-ettlinger/> 42 individuals have pleaded guilty.<ref name=doj-ettlinger/> 25 of the 42 individuals who have pleaded guilty for their roles in the conspiracy have been sentenced to prison and have received sentences ranging between 10 years and life in prison.<ref name=doj-ettlinger/> 15 of the 72 charged individuals remain at large and are known only by their online identities.<ref name=doj-ettlinger/> Efforts to identify and apprehend these individuals continue.<ref name=ice-wyss>{{cite web |url=http://www.ice.gov/news/releases/1205/120518washingtondc2.htm |title=Dreamboard member found guilty for participating in international criminal network organized to sexually exploit children |publisher=Ice.gov |date=2012-05-18 |accessdate=2014-03-25}}</ref>
* On January 8, 2013, David Ettlinger, aka ee1, 35, of Newton, Massachusetts was sentenced to serve 45 years in prison. In addition to his prison term, Ettlinger was sentenced to lifetime supervised release.<ref name=doj-ettlinger>{{cite web |url=http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/2013/January/13-crm-034.html |title=USDOJ: Dreamboard Member Sentenced to 45 Years in Prison for Participating in International Criminal Network Organized to Sexually Exploit Children |publisher=Justice.gov |date=2013-01-08 |accessdate=2014-03-25}}</ref>
On 29 July 2013 the final two defendants, of those arrested thus far, in the Dreamboard child exploitation and child pornography ring were sentenced to federal prison.<ref name=last-convicted/>
* Christopher Blackford, 28, of Charleston, S.C., was sentenced to 22 years in federal prison before U.S. District Court Judge S. Maurice Hicks in the Western District of Louisiana. In addition to his prison sentence, Blackford faces a lifetime of supervised release. Blackford admitted in his April guilty plea that he joined Dreamboard in December 2009 and contributed 84 posts to the online bulletin board that contained child pornography.<ref name=last-convicted/> * William Davis, 39, of Bristol, N.H., was sentenced to more than 17 years in federal prison in addition to a lifetime of supervised release. Davis admitted in his April guilty plea that he posted advertisements offering to distribute child pornography to other members of the board.<ref name=last-convicted>{{cite web |url=http://www.ice.gov/news/releases/1307/130731shreveport.htm |title=Final 2 in custody sentenced for largest child pornography case in US history |publisher=Ice.gov |date=2013-07-31 |accessdate=2014-03-25}}</ref>

'''Pierre Picaud''' ({{IPA-fr|piko|lang}}) was a 19th-century shoemaker in [[Nîmes]] who may have been the basis for the character of [[Edmond Dantès]] in [[Alexandre Dumas, père]]'s novel, ''[[The Count of Monte Cristo]]''. In 1807, Picaud was engaged to marry a rich woman, but three jealous friends — Loupian, Solari, and Chaubart — falsely accused him of being a [[spy]] for [[England]] (a fourth friend, Allut, knew of their conspiracy, but did not report it).<ref>H. Ashton-Wolfe, p. 19</ref> He was imprisoned in the [[Fenestrelle Fort|Fenestrelle]] fortress for seven years, not even learning why until his second year there.<ref>H. Ashton-Wolfe, p. 20-21</ref> During his imprisonment he ground a small passageway into a neighboring cell and befriended a wealthy [[Italian people|Italian]] priest named Father Torri who was being held there.<ref>H. Ashton-Wolfe, p. 22</ref> A year later, a dying Torri bequeathed to Picaud a treasure he had hidden in [[Milan]].<ref>H. Ashton-Wolfe, p. 23</ref> When Picaud was released after the fall of the Imperial government in 1814, he took possession of the treasure, returned under another name to [[Paris]] and spent 10 years plotting revenge against his former friends.
Picaud first murdered Chaubart, or had him murdered.<ref>H. Ashton-Wolfe, p. 27</ref> Picaud's former fiancée had, two years after his disappearance, married his former friend Loupian, who became the subject of his most brutal revenge. Picaud tricked Loupian's daughter into marrying a criminal, whom he then had arrested. Loupian's daughter promptly died of shock. Picaud then burned down Loupian's restaurant, or arranged to have it burned down, leaving Loupian impoverished.<ref>H. Ashton-Wolfe, p. 28</ref> Next, he poisoned Solari to death and either manipulated Loupian's son into stealing some gold jewelry or framed him for committing the crime.<ref>H. Ashton-Wolfe p. 29</ref> The boy was sent to jail, and Picaud stabbed Loupian to death. He was himself then abducted by Allut and killed.
Allut's deathbed confession forms the bulk of the French police records of the case. The detailed description of Picaud's experiences in prison, which could not have been known to Allut, were supposedly dictated to him by the ghost of Father Torri.<ref>H. Ashton-Wolfe p. 33</ref>
==Notes== <references/>

{{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=April 2009}} {{original research|date=April 2009}} {{globalize|date=October 2010}} }} '''Police impersonation''' is an act of falsely portraying oneself as a member of the [[police]], for the purpose of deception. In the vast majority of countries, the practice is illegal and carries a [[custodial sentence]].
Impersonating a [[police officer]] is sometimes committed in order to assert police-like authority in order to commit a crime. Posing as a police officer enables the offender to legitimize the appearance of an illegal act, such as: [[burglary]], making a [[traffic stop]], or [[Detention (imprisonment)|detaining]].
Dressing up as a police officer in costume (e.g. for [[Halloween]]), or pretending to be a police officer for the purpose of play or a harmless prank toward an acquaintance is generally not considered a crime, provided that those involved recognize the imposter is not a real police officer, and the imposter is not trying to deceive those involved into thinking they are. Nevertheless, replica police uniforms sold in the UK must not be identical to the uniforms currently used by the police, and traders have been jailed in the past for selling on genuine uniforms<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2874609/Police-uniform-trader-sold-helmets-truncheons-TV-shows-prosecuted-unable-prove-weren-t-bought-terrorists.html|title=Police uniform trader who sold helmets and truncheons to TV shows is prosecuted - Daily Mail Online|work=Mail Online}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2010/10_october/18/inside_out_southeast.shtml|title=BBC - Press Office - Inside Out South East reveals illegal trade in police uniforms|work=bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
The following impersonations class as the offence:
*'''Verbal identification''': The imposter announces to the unsuspecting victim that they are a police officer or other law enforcement agent. *'''Fake [[Badge]] or [[Warrant card]]''': The imposter, though not in any special clothes, displays a police-like badge or identification card to the victim. Sometimes, even a real police officer will not even be able to differentiate between the real and fake badge, as some duplicates are very similar to a real badge, if not identical to one. This is much more of a problem in the USA than in the UK, as in the UK, police identification includes photographic ID as well as the police shield, whereas in the USA, a police shield alone counts as ID, making it easier for people to pretend to be police officers. *'''Fake [[uniform]]''': The imposter wears a uniform that looks very much like that of a police officer. *'''Fake [[Police car|vehicle]]:''' The imposter places police lights (these can be either permanently mounted onto the car or temporary lights magnetically attached to the cartop), decals, siren, or other equipment on a personal vehicle to disguise it as a [[police car]] and enable the offender to pass through red traffic lights, bypass traffic other non-emergency traffic would have to wait for, make [[traffic stop]]s, or even [[arrest]]s.
Much of the equipment described above is available for purchase by the general public, thereby enabling imposters to obtain the necessary materials to commit such a crime. While the equipment will not bear the name of a specific law enforcement agency, the unsuspecting victim may not notice the difference.
In an extreme case, a [[Hempstead (village), New York|Hempstead, New York]] man set up a fake [[police station]] in addition to the above, where he [[Interrogation|interrogated]] those he [[arrest]]ed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.foxnews.com/story/alleged-fake-cop-ran-own-police-station-interrogated-suspects|title=Alleged Fake Cop Ran Own 'Police Station,' Interrogated 'Suspects'|work=Fox News}}</ref>
Some of the following crimes have been committed while impersonating a police officer:{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} *[[Burglary|Home invasion]], by gaining entry under the guise of a police officer, followed by [[theft]] from the premises, [[rape]], [[torture]], or in rare cases, [[murder]]. *'''Theft and [[motor vehicle theft]]''' - approaching a victim, explaining that an item or a vehicle is stolen. The impersonator will then seize the "evidence" and never return it. *[[Armed robbery]], following a [[traffic stop]] *[[Kidnapping]] following a traffic stop or [[false arrest]] *'''Fake authority''', in which the officer attempts to [[extortion|extort]] money from the victim, claiming it is a fine, or can be paid on the spot to avoid further legal consequences. *[[Prank]] phone calls and other [[fraudulent]] / deceptive electronic [[communications]], where one might make a comment about a group that invites retaliation.
==Popular culture== The 2014 American film ''[[Let's Be Cops]]'' features the main characters pretending to be police officers. A popular webseries ''[[Dick Figures]]'' aired an episode called 'We're Cops' featured 'red' and 'blue' rob a bank dressed as a police officer.
